questions.text: Which of the following medications is most commonly used for maintenance therapy in opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Buprenorphine:

  • Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist that is commonly used in maintenance therapy for opioid dependence. It helps manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings by binding to the same opioid receptors in the brain that full agonists like heroin or methadone do but with a ceiling effect that reduces the risk of misuse, respiratory depression, and overdose. Buprenorphine can be used alone or in combination with naloxone (as in Suboxone) to further deter misuse. It is an effective and widely used medication for maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Naloxone:

  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that is primarily used as a rescue medication in cases of opioid overdose. It rapidly reverses the effects of opioids, particularly respiratory depression. However, naloxone is not used for maintenance therapy in opioid withdrawal, as it would precipitate withdrawal symptoms in individuals dependent on opioids.

Option C - Naltrexone:

  • Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that is used in the maintenance treatment of opioid and alcohol dependence. For opioid dependence, naltrexone is used after detoxification to prevent relapse. It works by blocking the euphoric and sedative effects of opioids. While effective, it is not typically used during the initial withdrawal phase or for managing withdrawal symptoms but rather for relapse prevention in those who have already undergone detoxification.

Option D - Acamprosate:

  • Acamprosate is a medication used to help maintain abstinence in individuals with alcohol dependence. It works by modulating glutamatergic neurotransmission and is not used for opioid withdrawal or maintenance therapy. Acamprosate does not have any effect on opioid receptors and is specific to alcohol use disorder.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with elevated calcium levels, increased serum creatinine levels, and decreased hemoglobin. Electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal spike. Her immunofixation test findings are given below. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) MM with increased IgM

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is characterized by a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis, and the immunofixation test revealed increased IgM levels (a distinct band can be seen, whereas the smear pattern without any band formation above IgG is insignificant)

Serum Protein Electrophoresis in Multiple Sclerosis:

 

  • The gamma (Ig) will increase and show a spike an M spike - monoclonal or myeloma spike
  • Immunofixation - will tell the type of immunoglobulin

Immunofixation of MM with increased IgG

Incorrect Options:

MM with increased IgG (Option A): Smear pattern without any bands, so its not IgG

MM with increased IgA (Option C) : No protein fixation, so its not IgA

MGUS (Option D): In MGUS, gammaglobulins levels are <3gm/dL

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a mass felt on the perineum. On examination, a palpable uterus is noted, and from the os, one finger can pass. She delivered 20 years ago.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Myxomatous Polyp:

  • A myxomatous polyp is a benign, soft, gelatinous growth that can arise from the endometrial or cervical tissue. Given the history of remote childbirth, the polyp could have developed over time. The description of a mass on the perineum with a palpable uterus and a cervix that allows one finger to pass is consistent with a prolapsing myxomatous polyp.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Uterine Inversion:

  • Uterine inversion typically occurs immediately after childbirth and involves the uterus turning inside out. It presents acutely with severe pain and shock, not 20 years post-delivery. A palpable uterus with this scenario is unlikely, making uterine inversion an improbable diagnosis.

Option C - Placental Polyp:

  • Placental polyps result from retained placental tissue following childbirth or abortion. Given that the patient delivered 20 years ago, a placental polyp is unlikely because it would have presented earlier with complications like bleeding or infection.

Option – D Hypertrophied Cervix:

  • Cervical hypertrophy refers to an enlargement of the cervix, which can cause a mass effect. However, the clinical description of a perineal mass with a palpable uterus suggests something protruding rather than just a thickened cervix.

questions.text: Identify the labeling correctly:

choices.text: A- Superior vena cava, B- Ascending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta
A- Ascending aorta, B- Descending aorta, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Superior vena cava
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior vena cava, C- Descending aorta, D- Pulmonary trunk,
A- Ascending aorta, B- Superior Vena Cava, C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A- , B-Ascending aorta , C- Pulmonary trunk, D- Descending aorta:

  • A. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It is located anterior and slightly to the right of the ascending aorta.

  • B. Ascending aorta:  The ascending aorta arises from the left ventricle of the heart and is the initial portion of the aorta that moves upward before arching.

  • C. Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is the vessel that arises from the right ventricle and bifurcates into the left and right pulmonary arteries, which carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs. It is positioned anterior to the ascending aorta and the superior vena cava.

  • D. Descending Aorta: The descending aorta continues from the aortic arch and runs downwards behind the heart, supplying blood to the lower parts of the body. It is located posterior to the heart and more to the left in the thoracic cavity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B , C, D incorrectly labels the structures

questions.text: In the management of Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) of the lip, which biopsy technique is most appropriate to obtain a representative sample of the tumor?

choices.text: Superficial Biopsy from the Border with Normal Tissue

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Incisional Biopsy:

This involves removing a portion of the tumor along with a small margin of surrounding normal tissue. This technique is appropriate for larger or more advanced lesions where complete excision may be difficult or if the diagnosis needs confirmation before planning further treatment. It helps in diagnosing the cancer and planning the subsequent management.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option C - Superficial Biopsy from the Border with Normal Tissue:In SCC of the lip, obtaining a biopsy from the border of the lesion, where the tumor is likely to be more active and adjacent to normal tissue, is preferred. Biopsy from the central necrotic area may not provide representative tissue for accurate diagnosis and staging. This approach ensures that the sample is more likely to contain viable cancer cells, aiding in precise diagnosis and effective treatment planning.

Option B - Excisional Biopsy: This involves removing the entire tumor along with some surrounding normal tissue. This technique is often used for small, localized tumors and is typically preferred when a definitive diagnosis can be made, and the entire tumor can be removed in one procedure. For SCC of the lip, if the lesion is small and localized, an excisional biopsy can also serve as a treatment.

Option D - Contraindicated: The biopsy method for SCC of the lip is not contraindicated.

questions.text: A patient with loss of sensation on lateral 31/2 hand and thenar atrophy. Which nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Median:

  • Lateral 3½ fingers (thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of ring finger) on the palmar side are supplied sensory-wise by the median nerve.

  • Thenar atrophy suggests motor loss to thenar muscles, which are innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

  • These two features together are classic for median nerve injury, typically at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) or more proximally.

Nerves of the hand:

Nerve

Motor Dysfunction

Sensory Dysfunction

Common Deformity/Condition

Median Nerve

Weakness of thenar muscles (thumb opposition), flexor muscles of forearm

Loss of sensation in lateral 3.5 fingers (thumb, index, middle, half of the ring finger)

Ape hand (thenar atrophy), Carpal tunnel syndrome

Ulnar Nerve (Option B ruled out)

Weakness of intrinsic hand muscles (especially interossei), hypothenar muscles

Loss of sensation in medial 1.5 fingers (little and half of the ring finger)

Claw hand, Hypothenar atrophy, Cubital tunnel syndrome

Radial Nerve (Option C ruled out)

Inability to extend wrist and fingers (wrist drop)

Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand

Wrist drop, Saturday night palsy, Radial tunnel syndrome

Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN) (Option D ruled out)

Inability to flex thumb and index finger (loss of flexion of distal phalanges)

No sensory loss (pure motor neuropathy)

Inability to make "OK" sign (difficulty flexing thumb and index finger)

Long Thoracic Nerve

Weakness of serratus anterior muscle, affecting scapular movement

No sensory loss

Winged scapula (scapula protrudes from the back)

.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with hepatosplenomegaly, and his bone marrow showed 22% of plasma cells. Biopsy reveals pinkish acellular material deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the bone marrow

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Amyloidosis:

  • The given clinical features, along with increased plasma cells and microscopic findings of pinkish acellular material deposition, are suggestive of primary amyloidosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D do not show pinkish acellular material deposition.

questions.text: Using the radiograph provided, which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chiari type 1 malformation:

  • Chiari type 1 malformation is characterized by a small posterior fossa, which leads to herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dandy-Walker malformation: Dandy-Walker malformation is characterized by a large posterior fossa and the presence of a posterior fossa cyst.

Option C - Vein of Galen malformation: The vein of Galen malformation is identified by an enlarged vein of Galen on imaging.

Option D - Corpus callosum agenesis: Agenesis of the corpus callosum refers to the absence or underdevelopment of the corpus callosum, but it is seen in the given image.

questions.text: What investigation is being performed in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Barium swallow:

  • The given image sequence shows barium swallow.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Fluoroscopy: Fluoroscopy is depicted in a video or movie form.

Options C and D are not depicted in the image.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a known case of asthma presents with postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Which drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carboprost:

  • Carboprost is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction, which can exacerbate asthma symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Methyl ergometrine:

  • This drug is used to control PPH by stimulating uterine contractions. It is not contraindicated in asthma but should be used cautiously due to its potential to increase blood pressure.

Option C - Misoprostol:

  • A prostaglandin E1 analogue commonly used to treat PPH. It has a relatively safe profile in asthmatic patients and does not cause bronchoconstriction.

Option D - Oxytocin:

  • A first-line agent for treating PPH. It stimulates uterine contractions and is safe for use in asthmatic patients, with no risk of bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with sciatica had tender hamstrings. Which of the following supplies a hybrid muscle, which is spared in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Obturator Nerve:

  • This nerve supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh, which are part of the hybrid muscle group that is spared in sciatica. The obturator nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the adductor muscles (adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis) which are not affected in sciatica, as sciatica mainly involves the sciatic nerve and its branches.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Femoral Nerve: This nerve innervates the quadriceps and other muscles of the anterior thigh. In sciatica, the femoral nerve is generally not directly involved, but the tender hamstrings are more related to the sciatic nerve and its branches.

Option B - Common Peroneal Nerve: This is a branch of the sciatic nerve, and sciatica can affect it, leading to symptoms like foot drop. It does not provide significant innervation to the hybrid muscle group that is mentioned in this context.

Option D - Tibial Nerve: This is another branch of the sciatic nerve, and it innervates the posterior compartment of the leg and the plantar aspect of the foot. It is involved in sciatica and is not spared in this condition.

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with corneal ulcers and diminished vision. He was very careless about his lens fluid. On microscopy, an organism with spikes is identified. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acanthamoeba:

  • Acanthamoeba is most likely responsible for this patient's condition. Acanthamoeba keratitis is associated with improper use of contact lenses, and spikes are seen on microscopy.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not responsible for causing this patient’s condition, as explained above.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis occurs when one vertebra slips forward over the one below it, usually due to degeneration, trauma, or congenital defects. The CT scan in this case would show the misalignment of the vertebrae, explaining the patient's chronic back pain. This diagnosis is consistent with the clinical presentation and imaging findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paget's Disease:

  • Paget’s disease is a chronic bone disorder that can cause enlarged and deformed bones. On imaging, it typically shows thickened cortical bone, enlarged bones with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes, and a characteristic “cotton wool” appearance. This disease usually affects the pelvis, skull, spine, and long bones, but the imaging features would differ from those seen in spondylolisthesis.

Option B - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis leads to decreased bone density and increased fracture risk, especially in the spine, hips, and wrists. CT scans of patients with osteoporosis typically show generalized bone thinning, with possible compression fractures in the vertebrae, but not the characteristic vertebral slippage seen in spondylolisthesis.

Option D - Renal Osteodystrophy:

  • This is a bone pathology associated with chronic kidney disease, characterized by alterations in bone morphology. Imaging might show subperiosteal resorption, "rugger-jersey" spine, or osteosclerosis, but it would not show the vertebral slippage characteristic of spondylolisthesis.

questions.text: A physician is evaluating a patient for an occupational disease and finds that a coproporphyrin test has been performed. Which of the following conditions is most likely suspected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lead poisoning:

Lead Poisoning:

  • Coproporphyrin Test: Elevated levels of coproporphyrin in the urine are associated with lead poisoning. Lead interferes with heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of porphyrins and their precursors, including coproporphyrin.
  • Additional Symptoms: Lead poisoning can cause neurological symptoms, abdominal pain, anemia, and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Berylliosis: Symptoms: Berylliosis is an occupational lung disease caused by exposure to beryllium. It presents with symptoms similar to those of sarcoidosis and is diagnosed via chest X-ray and lung biopsy, not porphyrin levels.

Option C - Silicosis: Symptoms: Silicosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhaling silica dust. It is characterized by lung fibrosis and nodular lesions visible on chest X-rays. Porphyrin levels are not typically used in its diagnosis.

Option D - Asbestosis: Symptoms: Asbestosis results from exposure to asbestos fibers and is associated with lung fibrosis and pleural plaques. Diagnosis is made through history of exposure, chest X-ray, and lung function tests rather than porphyrin levels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with acute epigastric pain and elevated serum lipase. He was stabilized after three days. What is the most common pathology associated with the chest X-ray obtained?
questions.solution:
Correction Answer: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)

Explanation:

  • The patient has acute pancreatitis (suggested by epigastric pain + elevated serum lipase).

  • ARDS is a known pulmonary complication of acute pancreatitis, especially in severe cases due to inflammatory cytokine release.

  • ARDS typically develops within a few days of the primary illness and can be seen on chest X-ray as bilateral diffuse alveolar infiltrates without cardiomegaly.

Abdominal Pathology Causing Pulmonary Complications

Condition Primary Event Lung Complication Time of Onset Imaging Finding
Acute pancreatitis Inflammation, enzyme release ARDS Within 24–72 hours Bilateral infiltrates (non-cardiogenic)
Heart failure Volume overload Pulmonary edema Variable Bilateral perihilar haziness + cardiomegaly
Pulmonary embolism Thrombus in pulmonary arteries Infarcts, pleural-based opacities Sudden onset Wedge-shaped infarcts on CXR/CT
Miliary TB Disseminated TB infection Miliary nodules throughout lung Subacute/chronic Uniform millet-sized nodules

 

Acute pulmonary edema (Option B):
Incorrect because this usually shows perihilar bat-wing pattern and is associated with cardiac causes, which are not suggested here.

Pulmonary thromboembolism (Option C):
Incorrect as there is no sudden-onset dyspnea, chest pain, or risk factors for DVT/PE; and CT chest is usually needed, not just CXR.

Miliary TB (Option D):
Incorrect because miliary TB is chronic, not acute, and has constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss); not consistent with acute pancreatitis history.

questions.text: In the health education model, the first step is awareness; the second step is motivation. What is the third step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Action:

  • In the health education model, the third step is action.
  • Sequence in adoption of the message

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect, as given above.

questions.text: A woman presents with a twin pregnancy. On ultrasound, the estimated age of one fetus is 1 month more than the other fetus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Superfetation:

  • In the case of superfetation, it is possible to have fetuses at different developmental stages within the same pregnancy, resulting in an age discrepancy such as one fetus being one month older than the other. This is a rare and unusual occurrence and is the most fitting diagnosis for the described scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superfecundation:

  • This refers to the fertilization of two or more eggs during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse. It results in twins or multiple births with different paternity. This does not explain fetuses of different ages in the same pregnancy.

Option C - Suppositious Child:

  • This term is used to describe a child that is believed to be a result of surrogacy or another form of childbearing that may not be biologically related to the purported parents. It does not apply to the situation of differing fetal ages.

Option D - Posthumous Child:

This refers to a child born after the death of one or both parents. This term does not relate to the condition where fetuses of different ages are present in a single pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the markers in the given slide:

choices.text: A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland
A- Arrector pilorum, B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland
A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Apocrine gland, D-Sebaceous gland
A- Sebaceous gland, B- Apocrine gland, C- Eccrine sweat gland, D- Arrector pilorum

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland:

A - Eccrine Sweat Gland: Eccrine sweat glands are responsible for thermoregulation and are found throughout the body, primarily in the palms, soles, and forehead. They are characterized by their tubular structure and are often found deep in the dermis.

B - Arrector Pilorum: These are small muscles attached to hair follicles. When they contract, they cause the hair to stand up, commonly known as piloerection. They are typically found alongside hair follicles.

C - Sebaceous Gland: Sebaceous glands are responsible for producing sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. They are usually associated with hair follicles and appear as small clusters of cells in the dermis.

D - Apocrine Gland: Apocrine sweat glands are primarily found in the axillary and genital regions. They secrete a thicker, milky fluid into hair follicles and are involved in scent production. These glands are larger than eccrine glands and have a more complex structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These options are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient stopped antihypertensive medication due to dry eyes, dry mouth and constipation. After stopping the drug, he developed hypertensive emergency (BP > 180/120). Most likely drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clonidine:

  • Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It works by decreasing sympathetic outflow, which lowers blood pressure. When clonidine is stopped abruptly, it can lead to a rebound increase in blood pressure, potentially causing a hypertensive emergency. Symptoms like dry eyes, dry mouth, and constipation are common side effects of clonidine. Therefore, the development of a hypertensive emergency after stopping clonidine is consistent with its withdrawal effects.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lisinopril:

  • Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure. It typically does not cause rebound hypertension if discontinued. Common side effects include cough and elevated potassium levels, but not dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation. Discontinuation of lisinopril is unlikely to cause a hypertensive emergency.

Option C - Amlodipine:

  • Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to manage hypertension and angina. It generally does not cause rebound hypertension when stopped. Side effects can include swelling, dizziness, and flushing, but not dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation. Discontinuation of amlodipine is less likely to result in a hypertensive emergency.

Option D - Telmisartan:

  • Telmisartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). Similar to lisinopril, discontinuation of telmisartan typically does not cause rebound hypertension. Common side effects include dizziness and hyperkalemia, but not dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation. A hypertensive emergency due to the abrupt discontinuation of telmisartan is unlikely.

questions.text: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anterior talofibular ligament

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured structure in an inversion injury, as it is the weakest of the lateral ligaments and is directly stressed by inversion movements. The peroneus longus tendon, which helps evert the foot, can also be affected due to the force of the inversion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tibialis anterior tendon:

  • This tendon primarily functions to dorsiflex and invert the foot. While it plays a role in ankle stability, it is not typically injured in an inversion injury, which stresses the lateral ligaments rather than the anterior structures.

Option B - Tibialis posterior tendon:

  • This tendon is responsible for foot inversion and support of the medial arch. Injuries to the tibialis posterior tendon are more associated with overuse or medial stress rather than acute inversion injuries, which typically affect the lateral side of the ankle.

Option C - Extensor hallucis longus tendon:

  • This tendon controls the extension of the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is less commonly injured in inversion sprains, as it is not located in the lateral or medial regions of the ankle that bear the brunt of an inversion force.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Herbert pits:

  • The image shows scarring in the upper limbus, which is referred to as Herbert's pits. It is seen in the chronic cicatricial stage of trachoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Horner trantas spots:

Option C – Pannus:

Option D - Corneal dystrophy:

                                                                                       Microcystic/Map dot/ Fingerprint Dystrophy

                                                                              Meesmann dystrophy

 

                                                            Reis-Bucklers corneal dystrophy

questions.text: A patient who has undergone gastrectomy (surgical removal of part or all of the stomach) is at risk of deficiencies in certain nutrients. Which of the following vitamins is most likely to require supplementation in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vitamin B12:

  • A patient who has undergone gastrectomy is at risk of vitamin B12 deficiency due to the reduced production of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for vitamin B12 absorption. Therefore, vitamin B12 supplementation is typically required to prevent deficiency in such patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vitamin C: Although vitamin C is important for immune function and skin health, deficiency is not typically a direct result of gastrectomy. Patients may get enough vitamin C through their diet or supplements without specific concern related to gastrectomy.

Option B - Vitamin D: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and calcium absorption. While vitamin D deficiency can occur in various conditions, it is not specifically linked to gastrectomy. Patients may need to monitor vitamin D levels, but it is not the primary concern post-gastrectomy.

Option D - Vitamin A: Vitamin A is important for vision, skin health, and immune function. Deficiency in vitamin A is less commonly associated with gastrectomy compared to vitamin B12.

questions.text: Which type of ulcer is given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Venous ulcer:

  • These ulcers are commonly found on the lower legs, particularly around the ankles. They typically have irregular borders, are shallow, and may present with a moist base. They are associated with chronic venous insufficiency, where poor blood flow in the veins leads to high pressure and fluid leakage in the tissues. The skin around the ulcer may be discolored or have signs of eczema.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Arterial ulcer: These ulcers are generally found on the feet or toes and are characterized by well-defined, punched-out edges. They are usually painful, and the skin around the ulcer is often pale or cool to the touch. Arterial ulcers result from poor blood flow due to arterial disease, such as peripheral artery disease (PAD), which impairs oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues.

Option C - Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are less common and are associated with conditions that cause nerve damage, such as diabetes or leprosy. These ulcers are typically painless and occur on areas prone to trauma or pressure. The affected skin may be dry and necrotic, and the ulcers are usually located on areas with poor sensation.

Option D - Diabetic foot: Diabetic foot ulcers can occur anywhere on the foot and are often associated with diabetes-related neuropathy and peripheral vascular disease. They are typically found on pressure points and can have a deep, necrotic base. The ulcers may be surrounded by calloused skin and are often complicated by infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with headaches, palpitations, and hypertension. On laboratory examination, urine VMA is positive. His biopsy findings are given below. Which of the following is a correct statement?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Associated with MEN2A:

  • The given biopsy shows a nesting pattern or Zellballen pattern, which is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. It is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mostly malignant: Pheochromocytomas are mostly benign, only 10% malignant.

Option B - Mostly in children: Pheochromocytomas are more common in adults; only 10% occur in children.

Option C - Mostly bilateral: Pheochromocytomas are mostly unilateral, and only 10% are bilateral.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is likely to be caused by the lesion shown in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bitemporal hemianopia:

  • The radiograph in question shows a craniopharyngioma, which is a suprasellar mass located above the optic chiasma. It compresses the optic chiasma and causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not typically caused by craniopharyngioma.

questions.text: An adult tall male presents with subluxation of the lens, long arm span, pectus excavatum, and cardiac abnormalities. What is the most likely protein found to be defective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Fibrillin:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is highly suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to defective fibrillin, a protein essential for connective tissue integrity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not affected by Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials drug dosing is determined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phase 1:

  • This phase focuses on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients. The primary goal is to determine the drug's safety profile and establish an appropriate dose range. Dosing is initially determined based on preclinical data and adjusted as necessary based on observed effects and tolerability in this phase.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phase 2: In this phase, the drug's efficacy and further safety are assessed in a larger group of patients with the condition the drug is intended to treat. Although dosing strategies may be refined based on efficacy and side effects observed in Phase 2, the initial dose determination is generally established in Phase 1.

Option C - Phase 3: This phase involves large-scale testing of the drug in diverse populations to confirm its effectiveness, monitor side effects, and compare it with existing treatments. While Phase 3 can provide additional data on the optimal dosing regimen and long-term effects, the primary dosing determination occurs in Phase 1.

Option D - Phase 4: This phase, also known as post-marketing surveillance, occurs after the drug has been approved for general use. It focuses on long-term effectiveness, monitoring of adverse effects in the general population, and potential new uses. Dosing is not typically determined in Phase 4 but rather monitored for ongoing safety and effectiveness.

questions.text: Whose opinion is not needed for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks due to fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Lawyer

Explanation:

  • While legal advice may be necessary to navigate the legal aspects of MTP, their opinion is not required for the medical decision-making process regarding the termination of pregnancy due to fetal anomalies.

(Option A) Gynaecologist:

  • The opinion of a gynaecologist is essential for MTP, especially after 24 weeks, as they are responsible for assessing the health of the pregnant woman and the implications of continuing or terminating the pregnancy.

(Option B) Radiologist:

  • A radiologist’s input is crucial in cases of MTP after 24 weeks due to fetal anomalies. They provide diagnostic imaging, such as ultrasounds, to identify and confirm the presence of anomalies in the fetus.

(Option C) Lawyer:

  • A pediatrician's opinion is important in the context of MTP for severe anomalies, as they can provide insight into the potential outcomes and quality of life for the newborn if the pregnancy continues.

questions.text: A child presents with itchy lesions and diarrhea and has been advised to follow a gluten-free diet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Celiac disease

Explanation:

The presence of an itchy lesion along with gluten sensitivity is suggestive of celiac disease.

  • Itchy lesions → Suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis, a skin manifestation of celiac disease.

  • Diarrhea → Classic gastrointestinal symptom of malabsorption.

  • Gluten-free diet advised → Strongly points toward gluten sensitivity, which is central to celiac disease.

Celiac disease

  • Cause: Autoimmune reaction to gluten (in wheat, barley, rye)

  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal bloating, failure to thrive (in children), irritability, and skin lesions

  • Dermatologic sign: Dermatitis herpetiformis – intensely itchy, blistering rash (usually elbows, knees, buttocks)

  • Diagnosis: Positive anti-TTG or anti-endomysial antibodies; confirmed by duodenal biopsy

  • Treatment: Strict lifelong gluten-free diet

 

Incorrect Options:

Whipple's disease, Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis (Options B, C, and D) do not show gluten sensitivity.

questions.text: Ptosis in horner’s syndrome is due to paralysis of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superior Tarsal Muscle (Müller's Muscle):

  • This muscle is a smooth muscle that assists the levator palpebrae superioris in raising the upper eyelid. In Horner's syndrome, there is a disruption of the sympathetic innervation, leading to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle. This results in a mild ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Orbitalis:

  • Incorrect: The orbitalis muscle (also known as Müller's muscle) is not directly involved in eyelid movement but is instead associated with the structure of the orbit. It is not the cause of ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

Option C - Orbicularis Oculi:

  • Incorrect: The orbicularis oculi muscle is responsible for closing the eyelids and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It is not affected in Horner's syndrome and is not responsible for ptosis.

Option D - Sphincter Pupillae:

  • Incorrect: The sphincter pupillae muscle is responsible for constricting the pupil and is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system. It is not involved in eyelid movement and is not the cause of ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: Shanchol vaccine consists of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bivalent 2 doses:

  • This refers to a vaccine that targets two different strains of Vibrio cholerae and requires two doses for complete immunization. The Shanchol vaccine is a bivalent vaccine, meaning it covers two different strains of Vibrio cholerae (O1 and O139) and typically requires two doses for full protection.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presents with shortness of breath. Vitals are HR= 120/min, BP= 160/100. Echo shows diastolic collapse of ventricles. CT showed money bag appearance. Which is best for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pericardiocentesis:

Diagnosis: Cardiac Tamponade

  • The combination of shortness of breath, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, diastolic collapse of the ventricles on echocardiogram, and the "money bag" appearance on CT strongly suggests cardiac tamponade. The "money bag" appearance refers to the shape of the pericardial sac when it is filled with a significant amount of fluid, leading to the characteristic external compression of the heart.

Management: Pericardiocentesis:

  • The definitive treatment for cardiac tamponade is pericardiocentesis. This procedure involves the drainage of the accumulated fluid in the pericardial sac, which relieves the pressure on the heart, allowing normal cardiac function to resume. This intervention is urgent and life-saving.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start diuretic with BP monitoring: Diuretics are contraindicated in cardiac tamponade as they can decrease preload, further reducing cardiac output and worsening the patient's condition.

Option B - Intra-aortic balloon pump: An intra-aortic balloon pump is used to support the heart in cases of cardiogenic shock, but it is not effective in cardiac tamponade, where the primary issue is external compression of the heart, not inadequate pump function.

Option D - Ventricular assist device: A ventricular assist device is used in severe heart failure to help the ventricles pump blood. However, it is not appropriate for cardiac tamponade, where the problem is due to fluid accumulation in the pericardium rather than intrinsic ventricular failure.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a history of gastrointestinal helminth infection has a stool sample showing motile 200-micron larvae but no eggs. Identify the parasite:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strongyloides:

  • Rhabditiform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis hatch and migrate to the intestinal lumen and are excreted in stool. No eggs are seen.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D: Eggs are present in the stool sample.

questions.text: A female patient’s Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) findings reveal a Carhart's notch. Which of the following is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Schwartz sign:

  • Carhart's notch is a specific audiometric finding seen in otosclerosis, characterized by a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. Schwartz's sign is associated with otosclerosis, particularly in the active phase. This sign refers to a flamingo pink hue seen through the tympanic membrane due to increased vascularity of the mucoperiosteum overlying the otosclerotic focus.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are not seen in otosclerosis.

questions.text: Identify the degree of uterine prolapse.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Degree 3:

  • This degree of prolapse involves the organ protruding through the vaginal opening but remaining within the confines of the external genitalia. It is visibly external but not entirely outside the pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Degree 1:

  • This level of prolapse refers to a situation where the organ (e.g., the uterus or bladder) descends into the vaginal canal but does not extend past the vaginal opening. It is still within the pelvic cavity.

Option B - Degree 2:

  • In this stage, the organ extends to the vaginal opening but does not protrude outside the vaginal orifice. It is partially outside the pelvic cavity but not yet entirely external.

Option D - Degree 4:

  • This is the most severe form of prolapse. The organ is entirely outside the pelvis, and it can be observed protruding beyond the vaginal orifice.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a focal area of hair loss accompanied by scaling and itching, as shown in the image. The child’s sibling had a similar condition two years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tinea:

  • The child’s focal hair loss, scaling, and itching, along with the history of a similar condition in a sibling, are consistent with tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Alopecia areata: Causes smooth, well-defined patches of hair loss without scaling or itching.

Option C - Pyoderma: A bacterial skin infection that typically presents with pustules or ulcers, not scaling.

Option D - Pediculosis capitis: Head lice infestation, characterized by itching and nits, not focal hair loss with scaling.

questions.text: Example of SNRI antidepressant drug
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Reboxetine:

  • Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) and is used as an antidepressant. It affects norepinephrine reuptake exclusively and does not significantly impact serotonin levels.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Tramadol:

  • Tramadol is an analgesic with weak serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition properties but is not classified as a primary antidepressant or SNRI. It is mainly used for pain management, and its SNRI activity is a secondary effect rather than its primary indication.

Option C - Paroxetine:

  • Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). It primarily affects serotonin reuptake and does not significantly impact norepinephrine levels. Therefore, it is not classified as an SNRI.

Option D - Bupropion:

  • Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). It primarily affects norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake, but does not significantly impact serotonin levels, so it is not classified as an SNRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a sepsis patient in the ICU?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hyperglycemia:

  • This is a frequent complication of TPN, particularly in critically ill patients, such as those with sepsis (metabolic disorders). The high glucose content of TPN, combined with insulin resistance often seen in sepsis, can lead to significant elevations in blood glucose levels.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperlipidemia: TPN can sometimes lead to elevated lipid levels, especially if the lipid component is administered in excess. However, this is less common in the acute setting of a septic patient compared to hyperglycemia.

Option C - Hyperglyceridemia: While TPN contains lipids that can elevate glyceride levels, hyperglyceridemia is not as common or clinically significant as hyperglycemia in the acute management of sepsis.

Option D - Hypoglycemia: Although hypoglycemia can occur if TPN is suddenly stopped or if there is an insulin overdose, it is not a common complication during the administration of TPN, especially in a septic patient where hyperglycemia is more likely.

questions.text:
Sequence the events in neuromuscular action potential conduction: 


	Sodium channels open in the end plate
	Calcium enters at the nerve end plate
	Release of acetylcholine
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2 → 3 → 1:

Events in Neuromuscular Action Potential Conduction:

2. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate: Calcium ions enter the nerve terminal when an action potential reaches the nerve end. This influx of calcium is crucial for the subsequent release of neurotransmitters.

3. Release of acetylcholine: The entry of calcium ions into the nerve terminal triggers the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

1. Sodium channels open in the end plate: The binding of acetylcholine to receptors on the muscle end plate causes sodium channels to open, leading to an influx of sodium ions into the muscle cell and generating an action potential in the muscle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and C are incorrect as given above

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has consulted several plastic surgeons, seeking correction for a facial deformity that she perceives. Despite being examined and reassured by the surgeons and her family that no deformity is present, she remains convinced that her face requires surgery. She frequently checks her appearance and persists in requesting surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – SSRI:

  • The woman in the scenario is likely suffering from Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD). Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors are the first-line pharmacological treatment for BDD.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not the first-line management of body dysmorphic disorder.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic sidewall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cancer.
questions.solution:
Option C - Stage 3B:

  • This stage is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic sidewall and/or hydronephrosis (or a non-functioning kidney) caused by the tumor. Both the pelvic sidewall involvement and hydronephrosis are key features.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage 2B:

  • This stage involves the extension of the cancer beyond the cervix to the parametrium, but not to the pelvic sidewall or lower third of the vagina. Hydronephrosis is not present.

Option B - Stage 2A:

  • In this stage, the cancer extends beyond the cervix but does not involve the parametrium or pelvic sidewall. The vagina may be involved, but not the lower third. There is no involvement of the pelvic sidewall or hydronephrosis.

Option D - Stage 3A:

  • Cancer at this stage involves the lower third of the vagina but does not extend to the pelvic sidewall. Hydronephrosis is not present.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden diminution of vision, difficulty looking towards the light, and circumcorneal congestion with a hypopyon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acute anterior uveitis:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute anterior uveitis. The presence of a hypopyon is often seen in conditions like Behcet disease, which can typically cause non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C do not present with a hypopyon.

questions.text: How is transferrin saturation affected by iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Decreased:

  • Transferrin saturation is decreased in iron deficiency anemia because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin despite increased transferrin levels.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with an intrauterine device (IUD) in place, and the thread is clearly visible. The woman wants to keep the pregnancy. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Remove gently:

  • If the IUD thread is visible, the safest approach is to gently remove the IUD during the first trimester. Removal decreases the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, and the majority of pregnancies can proceed without complications after the IUD is removed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Leave IUD inside:

  • Leaving the IUD in place is generally not recommended if the thread is visible because the presence of an IUD increases the risk of complications such as miscarriage, infection, and preterm birth. The preferred approach is to remove the IUD to reduce these risks.

Option C - MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy):

  • This option might be considered if the woman does not want to continue the pregnancy or if there are significant risks associated with the pregnancy. However, since the woman wants to keep the pregnancy, this option is not appropriate.

Option D - Cesarean section:

Cesarean section is not relevant at this stage, as it pertains to delivery rather than managing an early pregnancy with an IUD in place.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases follows the mode of inheritance shown in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

The given pedigree shows X-linked recessive inheritance, which is seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

 

Incorrect Options:

Wilson's disease (Option B): Autosomal recessive inheritance

Prader-Willi syndrome (Option C): Genomic imprinting disorder (not a classic Mendelian pattern)

Achondroplasia (Option D): Autosomal dominant

questions.text: In sacrocolpopexy (Sacrocolposuspension), the surgical mesh is attached to which bony landmark?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sacral promontory:

  • In sacrocolpopexy, a surgical procedure used to treat pelvic organ prolapse, the mesh is attached to the anterior longitudinal ligament over the sacral promontory. This provides strong support to the vaginal vault or uterus, effectively restoring normal pelvic anatomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ischial spine:

  • The ischial spine is a point of attachment for ligaments and muscles in the pelvis but is not used as an attachment site for the mesh in sacrocolpopexy.

Option C - Pubic symphysis:

  • The pubic symphysis is the joint between the two pubic bones at the front of the pelvis. It is not involved in sacrocolpopexy, as this procedure focuses on securing the vagina or uterus to the sacral promontory, located posteriorly in the pelvis.

Option D - Ischial tuberosity:

  • The ischial tuberosity is the lower part of the pelvis, serving as an attachment point for the hamstring muscles. It is not relevant to sacrocolpopexy, where the goal is to support pelvic organs by securing the mesh to the sacral promontory.

questions.text: When do you put a victim in the following position?

choices.text: Conscious patient with pulse & breathing present.
Unconscious patient with pulse & breathing present.
Unconscious patient with pulse present but no breathing.
Unconscious patient without pulse but breathing present.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Unconscious patient with pulse and breathing present

  • The image shows the recovery position (also known as the lateral recumbent position), which is used in first aid.

  • This position is specifically indicated when a person is unconscious but breathing and has a pulse, and there is no evidence of spinal injury.

  • It keeps the airway open, prevents aspiration of vomit or secretions, and promotes drainage from the mouth.

When to use the Recovery Position

Patient Status Recovery Position Used? Reason
Conscious with pulse & breathing (Option A) No No need to alter position unless needed for comfort or other reasons.
Unconscious with pulse & breathing (Option B) Yes Prevents airway obstruction and aspiration.
Unconscious with pulse but no breathing (Option C) No Requires rescue breathing or CPR, not recovery position.
Unconscious without pulse but breathing (Option D) No This is physiologically unlikely; no pulse = no circulation.

questions.text: A female presented with 1x 1 cm thyroid swelling. What is next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - TSH and T4:

  • The initial evaluation of thyroid swelling should include testing for thyroid function, which involves measuring TSH and T4 levels. This approach helps determine whether the thyroid gland is functioning normally or if there are abnormalities, such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, that could influence the management plan for the thyroid nodule. This information is crucial for deciding whether additional diagnostic procedures, such as a thyroid ultrasound or fine needle aspiration

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - I-131 (Radioactive Iodine Therapy): I-131 is used primarily for treating hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer, not for initial evaluation of a thyroid swelling. It is not appropriate for the initial assessment of a thyroid nodule.

Option B - TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone) Test: TSH is a crucial initial test for evaluating thyroid function. It helps determine if the thyroid is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). However, TSH alone does not provide information about thyroid hormone levels or nodule characteristics, which are also important.

Option D - T3 (Triiodothyronine) and T4 (Thyroxine) Test: T3 and T4 levels measure thyroid hormone levels, but TSH is more useful for assessing overall thyroid function. T3 levels are less commonly measured unless specifically indicated, as TSH and T4 are typically sufficient for initial evaluation.

questions.text:
Calculate the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for the year 2023, given the following events:


	Total women who died: 6
	Total live births: 4000
	Causes of death:
	1 due to road traffic accident (RTA)
	1 due to sepsis
	1 due to obstructed labor
	1 due to eclampsia
	1 due to ectopic pregnancy
	1 due to snake bite
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 100:

  • Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal deaths include those caused by complications of pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, excluding accidental or incidental causes.
  • Identifying Maternal Deaths:
  • Maternal deaths: Sepsis, obstructed labor, eclampsia, ectopic pregnancy.
  • Non-maternal deaths: Road traffic accident (RTA), snake bite.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A patient has pleural fluid with an LDH level greater than 0.6 times the serum LDH and protein greater than 0.5 times the serum protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tuberculosis (TB):

  • The pleural fluid analysis shows an LDH level greater than 0.6 times the serum LDH and protein greater than 0.5 times the serum protein, which are criteria for an exudative pleural effusion according to Light's criteria. Tuberculosis is a common cause of exudative pleural effusion, especially in areas where TB is prevalent. Exudative effusions occur due to increased capillary permeability or lymphatic obstruction, and they are often associated with infections, malignancies, and inflammatory conditions like TB.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Heart failure: Heart failure typically causes a transudative pleural effusion, which is characterized by lower protein and LDH levels in the pleural fluid relative to serum levels. This option is incorrect because the fluid described meets the criteria for an exudative effusion, not a transudative one.

Option C - Hepatic failure: Hepatic failure (such as in cirrhosis) usually causes a transudative pleural effusion due to low oncotic pressure from hypoalbuminemia, not an exudative effusion. Therefore, it is not the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

Option D - Renal failure: Renal failure can cause pleural effusions, but they are typically transudative unless complicated by infections or other factors. The described pleural fluid characteristics are more consistent with an exudative process.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency
Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII
Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood
Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood:

  • This statement is incorrect. Type 1 von Willebrand disease is the mildest form of the condition and is characterized by a partial deficiency of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Patients typically experience mild bleeding symptoms rather than severe ones. It often presents with mild bleeding tendencies rather than severe, and symptoms may not be apparent until later in life.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by a qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor, which leads to a moderate bleeding tendency. This type includes several subtypes with different defects in the von Willebrand factor.

Option B - Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII: This statement is partially correct but misleading. Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a severe deficiency or absence of von Willebrand factor, not factor VIII. However, since von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII, the absence of vWF can lead to very low levels of factor VIII.

Option D - Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes several subtypes (e.g., 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N), each with different defects affecting the function of von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Na/I symporter:

  • The Na/I symporter (NIS) is responsible for the active transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells. It uses the sodium gradient to co-transport iodine into the cell from the bloodstream.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pendrin: Pendrin is an iodide/chloride exchanger located on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells. It is involved in the movement of iodide into the follicle lumen but not in the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells.

Option C - Cl/I symporter: This option is incorrect as there is no known Cl/I symporter in the thyroid. Iodide transport into the thyroid follicle is not mediated by a chloride/iodide symporter.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in the improvement of insulin resistance in Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2) with regular exercise and physical activities?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - GLUT 4:

  • This glucose transporter is found predominantly in muscle and adipose tissue. GLUT 4 is regulated by insulin and is crucial for the insulin-mediated uptake of glucose into these tissues. Regular exercise increases the number of GLUT 4 receptors on the cell membrane, improving glucose uptake and insulin sensitivity in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GLUT 1: This glucose transporter is found in various tissues, including the brain and erythrocytes. It helps in the uptake of glucose across cell membranes but is not primarily responsible for the insulin-mediated glucose uptake in muscle cells.

Option B - GLUT 2: This glucose transporter is located primarily in the liver, pancreas, and kidneys. It plays a role in glucose sensing and regulation of blood glucose levels but does not directly mediate the improvement of insulin resistance through physical activity.

Option C - GLUT 3: This glucose transporter is found mainly in neurons and some other tissues. It is responsible for the uptake of glucose into the brain but does not significantly impact insulin resistance in skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Identify the given fracture:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Chance fracture:

  • The given radiograph shows a chance fracture. Chance fracture usually occurs at the thoracolumbar junction (T10-L2). It is a horizontal fracture that extends through the spinous process, pedicles, and vertebral body, affecting the posterior and middle columns of the spine.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Compression Fracture: The vertebral body becomes wedge-shaped due to the collapse of the anterior portion, with the posterior height usually preserved.

Option B - Burst Fracture: The vertebral body is shattered, with fragments extending into the spinal canal, potentially causing spinal cord compression.

Option D - Impacted fracture: Impacted Fracture shows overlapping bone fragments leading to increased density at the site of injury.

questions.text: A patient complains of eye pain and difficulty seeing after watching a movie. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mannitol with pilocarpine:

  • The scenario describes a patient presenting with symptoms after watching a movie, which is suggestive of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APACG). Mannitol helps to reduce intraocular pressure rapidly, and pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and pulls the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, thereby opening the drainage angle.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and D: Moxifloxacin and carboxymethylcellulose have no effect on intraocular pressure.

Option C: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which can worsen angle closure by increasing the pupillary block.

questions.text: What is the typical pressure setting for the valve in a Mapleson circuit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 30–40 cm H₂O,

Explanation:

  • The APL (Adjustable Pressure Limiting) valve in a Mapleson circuit is typically set to allow pressures up to 30–40 cm H₂O, especially during controlled ventilation.

  • This pressure helps ensure adequate ventilation, especially in scenarios like positive pressure ventilation under anesthesia.

  • It does not mean the pressure constantly stays at 30–40 cm H₂O, but that the valve opens when pressures rise to this range, preventing further pressure buildup.

Mapleson Circuit 

Feature Details
Used in Anesthesia, manual or controlled ventilation
APL Valve Purpose Limits peak airway pressure by releasing excess gas
Valve Pressure Setting Typically 30–40 cm H₂O, especially during controlled ventilation
Spontaneous Ventilation Use Valve kept open to atmosphere (minimal resistance)
Risk if too high >40 cm H₂O may cause barotrauma
Units Used cm H₂O (not mm Hg) in respiratory and anesthesia circuits

 

30–40 mm Hg (Option B): Incorrect because 30 mm Hg ≈ 40.8 cm H₂O — the unit is not standard for respiratory pressures.

10–20 cm H₂O (Option C): Incorrect for APL valve setting; this is more typical for PEEP or lower pressure alarms, not the opening pressure of the APL valve in controlled ventilation.

10–20 mm Hg (Option D): Incorrect both in unit (mm Hg) and value — 10 mm Hg ≈ 13.6 cm H₂O, which is lower than required for safe manual ventilation in controlled settings.

questions.text: What condition is indicated by the MRCP image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Choledochal cyst:

  • The given MRCP image shows a fusiform dilatation of the common hepatic and common bile ducts, which is suggestive of a choledochal cyst.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not seen in the given image.

questions.text: A child with untreated ADHD is most likely to develop which of the following disorders during adolescence?

choices.text: Separation from parent leading to depression

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Conduct disorder:

  • Children with untreated ADHD are at an increased risk of developing conduct disorder during adolescence.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are less likely to develop in the adolescence of a child with untreated ADHD.

questions.text: A child presents with skin eruptions upon exposure to sunlight and is diagnosed with a DNA repair defect. Which type of repair defect is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nucleotide excision repair defect:

  • Xeroderma pigmentosa is caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair, leading to an inability to repair UV-induced DNA damage, which results in extreme sensitivity to sunlight and a high risk of skin cancers.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not cause xeroderma pigmentosa.

questions.text: Drug for HIV induced lipodystrophy:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tesamorelin:

  • Tesamorelin is a synthetic growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) analog that is used specifically for reducing abdominal fat in patients with HIV-associated lipodystrophy. It works by stimulating the release of growth hormone, which helps to reduce visceral fat accumulation. It is the primary medication approved for this indication.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Somatropin:

  • Somatropin is a recombinant growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiencies and growth disorders. It is not specifically indicated for HIV-induced lipodystrophy, although it may have some effect on body composition. Its use is more general and not targeted at HIV-associated lipodystrophy.

Option C - Octreotide:

  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analog used to treat conditions like acromegaly and certain types of tumors. It is not used for treating HIV-induced lipodystrophy. Its effects are related to inhibiting growth hormone release rather than addressing fat distribution issues related to HIV.

Option D - Pegvisomant:

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the action of growth hormone at its receptor. It is not used for treating HIV-induced lipodystrophy, as its mechanism does not target fat redistribution or accumulation associated with HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Αβ 40 and 42:

  • αβ 40 and 42 are amyloid-beta peptides that are deposited in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease, forming plaques.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Synuclein: This is associated with Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

Option C - Polyglutamine: This is associated with Huntington's disease.

Option D - FUS: This is associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test. His platelet count is 25,000. Which of the following is the most important prognostic feature in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low platelet count:

  • In this clinical scenario, the most important prognostic feature for the 3-year-old boy presenting with a rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test, along with a platelet count of 25,000, is the low platelet count.
  • This is because a significantly low platelet count is directly associated with a higher risk of bleeding complications and is crucial for determining the management and prognosis of the condition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Elevated total leukocyte count (TLC):

  • While an elevated TLC may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation, it is less directly related to the prognosis of bleeding risk compared to platelet count. In conditions with bleeding, the platelet count is a more immediate indicator of potential complications.

Option C - Hematocrit:

  • Hematocrit measures the proportion of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. While it can provide information on anemia or blood volume status, it is not the primary prognostic factor for bleeding disorders related to low platelet counts.

Option D - Peripheral smear:

  • A peripheral smear can reveal the morphology of blood cells and help in diagnosing various hematological conditions. However, in the context of immediate bleeding risk and prognosis, platelet count is more critical than the peripheral smear findings.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with recurrent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy following finding. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pseudomembranous colitis:

  • This condition is characterized by inflammation of the colon due to an overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile, often after antibiotic use. The hallmark of this disease on colonoscopy is the presence of raised, yellowish-white plaques or pseudomembranes on the mucosa, which can be seen as the yellowish findings described. Symptoms include recurrent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP): FAP is an inherited disorder characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. Patients typically do not present with recurrent diarrhea or foul-smelling stools but are at high risk for colorectal cancer. The colonoscopy findings in FAP would show numerous polyps rather than pseudomembranes.

Option C - Ulcerative colitis: This is an inflammatory bowel disease that causes chronic inflammation and ulceration of the colonic mucosa. While patients may present with abdominal pain and diarrhea, the colonoscopy findings usually show continuous inflammation and ulceration, not pseudomembranes.

Option D - Acute gastritis: This condition involves inflammation of the stomach lining and typically presents with upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting rather than diarrhea. Colonoscopy is not used to diagnose gastritis as it affects the stomach, not the colon.

questions.text: A young athlete underwent testing for a competition and was found to have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following will increase the murmur in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Valsalva Maneuver:

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition characterized by the thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the interventricular septum, which can obstruct blood flow out of the left ventricle, leading to a systolic murmur. The murmur associated with HCM is dynamic and can change in intensity with different maneuvers that affect the volume of blood in the left ventricle.
  • The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced left ventricular filling. In HCM, this reduction in ventricular volume increases the obstruction to blood flow, making the murmur louder. This maneuver accentuates the outflow tract obstruction by bringing the hypertrophied septum closer to the anterior mitral valve leaflet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Handgrip: The handgrip maneuver increases systemic vascular resistance, which typically increases murmurs of regurgitant lesions like mitral regurgitation but decreases the murmur in HCM because the increased afterload reduces the degree of outflow tract obstruction.

Option C - Squatting: Squatting increases venous return and systemic vascular resistance, leading to increased left ventricular filling and a reduction in the outflow tract obstruction. This typically softens the murmur in HCM.

Option D - Leaning Forward: Leaning forward can accentuate murmurs of aortic regurgitation but does not have a significant effect on the murmur of HCM.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known case of homocystinuria presents with joint pain and weakness. Which vitamin is required for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vitamin B6:

  • Homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. Supplementing with Vitamin B6 can help reduce homocysteine levels and alleviate symptoms like joint pain and weakness.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not preferred in the management of this patient.

questions.text: A child presents with leukocoria and an intraocular mass. Microscopic examination reveals rosettes with scanty cytoplasm, and the mass is positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Retinoblastoma:

  • The presence of an intraocular mass in a child with leukocoria is suggestive of retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and Homer Wright rosettes are characteristic histopathological features of retinoblastoma. It is positive for synaptophysin, NSE, and chromogranin.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not align with the features described in the question.

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smelling sputum, breathlessness, and fever. Based on the X-ray below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lung abscess:

  • The given image shows an abscess cavity with an air-fluid level. The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings suggest a lung abscess.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pneumothorax: It will appear black on X-ray.

Option C - Pleural effusion: In the PA view, the fluid starts accumulating in the costophrenic angle (dependent part). So, blunting of the costophrenic angle is present.

Option D - Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion will show water bottle configuration.

questions.text: In the given graph, identify the type of inhibition:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Competitive:

  • In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme, often resulting in an increased Km without affecting Vmax.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as explained.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is receiving a combination antiretroviral therapy including Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine for HIV management. Which of the following drugs should be avoided due to potential drug interactions with this regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A4, which can significantly lower the plasma concentrations of Nevirapine. Nevirapine is metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme, and induction of this enzyme by rifampicin can lead to subtherapeutic levels of Nevirapine, reducing its effectiveness in managing HIV. This interaction can lead to treatment failure and the development of drug resistance. Therefore, rifampicin should be avoided or used with extreme caution, and alternative antiretroviral drugs or anti-tuberculosis medications should be considered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptomycin:

  • Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for the treatment of tuberculosis. It does not have significant interactions with the antiretroviral drugs Zidovudine, Lamivudine, or Nevirapine. Therefore, it can be used safely in combination with this regimen without the risk of significant drug interactions.

Option C - INH (Isoniazid):

  • Isoniazid (INH) is commonly used in the treatment and prophylaxis of tuberculosis. It does not significantly interact with Zidovudine, Lamivudine, or Nevirapine, and can generally be used safely in patients receiving this combination antiretroviral therapy. There may be some concern about hepatotoxicity when used with other hepatotoxic drugs, but this does not constitute a direct contraindication.

Option D - Ethambutol:

  • Ethambutol is another first-line anti-tuberculosis medication. It has minimal drug interactions with antiretroviral drugs, including Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine. Ethambutol can be used safely in combination with this HIV regimen without significant concerns for drug interactions.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated in a manner shown in the x ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary Healing:

  • The type of fracture healing you can expect in a fracture treated with rigid internal fixation, as shown in the X-ray, is primary healing. This type of healing is characterized by the direct formation of bone across the fracture site with minimal callus formation, due to the stable and precise alignment of the fracture fragments provided by rigid internal fixation.

 

Incorret Options:

Option B - Secondary Healing:

  • This process involves the formation of a callus and is associated with more motion at the fracture site compared to primary healing. Secondary healing occurs in two stages: the formation of a soft callus followed by a hard callus, and finally, remodeling of the callus into mature bone. This type of healing is more common with fractures treated with casts or less stable fixation.

Option C - Creeping Substitution:

  • This term refers to the gradual replacement of fibrocartilage or woven bone with lamellar bone during the healing process, often observed in secondary healing. It is not a distinct type of fracture healing on its own but rather a part of the secondary healing process.

Option D - Intramembranous Ossification:

  • This type of bone formation occurs directly within a membrane-like layer of connective tissue and is commonly seen in flat bones of the skull and the clavicle. It is not typically associated with fracture healing but rather with the development of bone during embryonic growth and the healing of certain types of fractures like those involving the skull.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension presents with atrial fibrillation, shortness of breath and Bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Least important in management would be:

choices.text: Start on anticoagulants like warf or Doac
Cardioversion to correct rhythm if hemodynamically remain unstable even after medical management

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Start beta blocker:

  • Beta blockers are used to control heart rate and manage symptoms related to atrial fibrillation. However, in acute settings with symptoms like shortness of breath and bilateral crackles, especially if heart failure is suspected, other treatments might take precedence. In cases of acute heart failure or unstable hemodynamics, immediate rate control might be achieved using other agents.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start on anticoagulants like warfarin or DOAC: Anticoagulants are crucial in the management of atrial fibrillation to prevent thromboembolic events such as stroke. Given the patient's symptoms and history, anticoagulation should be considered unless contraindicated.

Option C - Cardioversion to correct rhythm if hemodynamically unstable even after medical management: If the patient remains hemodynamically unstable despite medical management, cardioversion is necessary to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize the patient. This is crucial in managing acute atrial fibrillation.

Option D - IV Digoxin to control rate: IV digoxin is used for rapid rate control in atrial fibrillation, especially when accompanied by heart failure. It can be beneficial in acute settings for managing symptoms and controlling the ventricular rate.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses is an adnexal mass on ultrasound showing incomplete septation and a cogwheel appearance most consistent with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Hydrosalpinx:

  • This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, which can cause it to appear as a cystic mass on ultrasound. While hydrosalpinx typically appears as a smooth-walled, anechoic structure, it can sometimes show incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance, especially in chronic cases with associated inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Follicular ovarian cyst:

  • These are simple cysts formed from unruptured ovarian follicles. On ultrasound, they typically appear as round, anechoic structures with a thin, smooth wall and do not usually display incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance.

Option C - Endometriosis:
