  • Endometriosis can cause cysts called endometriomas, which often have a "chocolate" appearance due to old blood. On ultrasound, endometriomas typically present as well-defined cystic lesions with a homogeneous internal echogenicity and do not usually show incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance.

Option D - Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst:

  • This type of cyst occurs when a follicular cyst bleeds into itself. It can present with internal echoes or a complex appearance on ultrasound, including a cogwheel appearance due to blood clot formation and septations. However, incomplete septation is less characteristic compared to a hydrosalpinx.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient is suffering from frequent attacks of renal colic. Preferred anti hypertensive drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydrochlorothiazide:

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic commonly used to treat hypertension. It is particularly useful in patients with renal colic due to its ability to reduce calcium excretion in the urine, which can help prevent the formation of calcium-containing kidney stones. Thiazide diuretics are effective in managing hypertension and have a protective effect against stone formation by decreasing calcium levels in the urine.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ethacrynic Acid:

  • Ethacrynic acid is a loop diuretic and is not typically used for hypertension in the long term. It is used in situations where more potent diuresis is required or where thiazide diuretics are ineffective. Loop diuretics can increase calcium excretion in the urine, which could exacerbate kidney stone formation rather than prevent it.

Option B - Acetazolamide:

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that works as a diuretic but is not commonly used for hypertension. It can lead to increased bicarbonate excretion and subsequent metabolic acidosis. It is more commonly used in conditions like glaucoma, altitude sickness, or metabolic alkalosis. Its effect on calcium excretion is not beneficial for preventing renal colic.

Option D - Spironolactone:

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing aldosterone. It is used to treat conditions like heart failure, primary aldosteronism, and as part of combination therapy for hypertension. However, it does not affect calcium excretion and is not typically used for managing renal colic or calcium-based kidney stones.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tingling sensation in both legs, polyuria, and weight loss. Based on the given bone marrow aspirate findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Multiple myeloma with renal failure:

  • The bone marrow aspirate shows intranuclear inclusions known as Dutcher's bodies, which are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma often presents with renal failure, polyuria (due to hypercalcemia), and tingling sensations (due to amyloid deposition or hypercalcemia-related neuropathy).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not show Dutcher bodies on bone marrow biopsy.

questions.text: At which of the following ages does maximum brain growth occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 year:

  • The first year of life is marked by the most rapid brain growth. By the end of the first year, the brain reaches about 60% of its adult size. This period is critical for neurodevelopment, with significant increases in brain volume and neural connections.

Incorrect options:

Option B - 2 years:

  • Brain growth continues, but the rate slows down after the first year. By 2 years of age, the brain is approximately 75% of its adult size, but the most intense phase of growth has already occurred.

Option C - 3 years:

  • By 3 years, the brain is about 80-85% of its adult size. Growth is still significant, but it is not as rapid as during the first year.

Option D - 4 years:

  • The brain's growth rate further decreases, reaching around 90% of its adult size by this age. Most brain development in terms of structure is completed, but functional maturation continues.

questions.text: A central line infection is noted in an ICU patient, and staining shows a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Candida:

  • Candida species are yeast-like fungi that reproduce by budding and can cause central line infections, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Option C - Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis are gram-positive cocci in clusters, not oval-shaped.

Option D - Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli are gram-negative rods.

questions.text: A floppy infant presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and an X-ray showing cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pompe disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder (Type II) caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase (acid maltase). It leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac and skeletal muscle.
 

Clinical features include:

  • Floppy infant with profound hypotonia ("floppy baby")

  • Cardiomegaly due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Hepatomegaly from glycogen accumulation

  • Respiratory distress and feeding difficulties
    The combination of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly on X-ray fits classic infantile Pompe disease.

 

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) (Option B): TGA is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with discordant ventriculoarterial connections. Presents with cyanosis, not hypotonia or hepatomegaly. Cardiomegaly may be present, but hepatomegaly and hypotonia are not typical.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (Option C): TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with right ventricular outflow obstruction, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and RV hypertrophy. Presents with cyanosis and "tet spells." Hypotonia and hepatomegaly are not usual features.

Ebstein's anomaly (Option D): A congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve causing atrialization of the right ventricle. Presents with cyanosis, heart failure signs, but does not typically cause hypotonia or hepatomegaly in infancy.

questions.text: What is the appropriate management for a patient presenting with constant chest pain and radiological findings of stanford type A aortic dissection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Surgical Management:

  • Surgical intervention is indicated in cases of aortic dissection, especially if the dissection involves the ascending aorta or if there are signs of compromise to vital organs. Surgery is typically required for Type A aortic dissections (involving the ascending aorta) due to the high risk of life-threatening complications. Immediate surgical repair aims to stabilize the aorta, prevent further dissection, and manage complications.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vasodilator: Vasodilators alone are not typically the first-line treatment for aortic dissection. While they can help manage hypertension, they do not address the critical need to control the force of blood flow through the aorta, which is crucial in the acute management of dissection.

Option C - Beta Blocker: Beta blockers are a cornerstone in the medical management of aortic dissection. They reduce heart rate and blood pressure, thereby decreasing the shear stress on the aortic wall and preventing further dissection. Beta blockers are particularly important in Type B dissections (involving only the descending aorta) where surgery may not be immediately necessary.

Option D - Beta Blocker plus Vasodilator: In some cases, a combination of beta blockers and vasodilators may be used to manage blood pressure and reduce heart rate. However, for aortic dissection, the immediate priority is to control blood pressure and heart rate, with beta blockers being the primary treatment. Vasodilators can be used in conjunction if needed to further control blood pressure, but they are not a replacement for beta blockers.

questions.text: Identify the procedure commonly performed in patients with recurrent gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 360-degree Nissen fundoplication:

  • It is the most common surgical procedure performed for recurrent GERD. In this procedure, the fundus of the stomach is wrapped completely (360 degrees) around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, preventing acid reflux.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Partial gastrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of a portion of the stomach. It is not typically used for GERD treatment but rather for conditions like stomach cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease.

Option C - Esophageal banding: This procedure involves placing a band around the esophagus, typically used to treat esophageal varices in patients with portal hypertension, not for GERD.

Option D - 270-degree Nissen fundoplication: Also known as Toupet fundoplication, this procedure involves a partial (270 degrees) wrap of the stomach around the esophagus. While it can be used to treat GERD, it is less common than the 360-degree Nissen fundoplication, particularly in cases of recurrent GERD.

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory distress and is diagnosed with pan-acinar emphysema. Which deficiency is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not cause pan-acinar emphysema.

questions.text: A young girl presents with multiple episodes of loss of consciousness, each lasting about 20 minutes. These episodes occur exclusively in front of her family and only during the daytime. There is no history of tongue biting or incontinence associated with the episodes. Both EEG and MRI brain scans are normal. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Insight-oriented psychotherapy:

  • The clinical scenario described suggests that the patient is experiencing pseudoseizures, which are often a manifestation of a conversion disorder. Insight-oriented psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for conversion disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not preferred in the management of conversion disorder.

questions.text: A patient with raised triglyceride started on medication. He soon developed flushing, gout and raised liver enzymes. Likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nicotinamide (Niacin):

  • Niacin (nicotinic acid, not to be confused with nicotinamide) is commonly used to lower triglycerides and raise HDL cholesterol. However, it is known to cause several side effects, including flushing, hyperuricemia (which can precipitate gout), and elevated liver enzymes (indicating hepatotoxicity). Flushing is a particularly well-known side effect due to the vasodilatory effect of niacin, which can be mitigated by taking aspirin before the dose.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Atorvastatin:

  • Atorvastatin, a statin, is used to lower LDL cholesterol and triglycerides. While it can cause elevated liver enzymes and muscle-related side effects (myopathy), it is not typically associated with flushing or gout.

Option C - Fenofibrate:

  • Fenofibrate is a fibrate that is effective in lowering triglycerides. It can occasionally cause elevated liver enzymes and muscle-related side effects, but it is not typically associated with flushing or gout.

Option D - Cholestyramine:

  • Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant used to lower LDL cholesterol. It can cause gastrointestinal side effects such as constipation but is not associated with flushing, gout, or elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Copper:

  • Anaemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmented skin and hair are seen in copper deficiency.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not present with the given findings.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures can cause a deformity as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Supracondylar fractures of the humerus, especially in children, can lead to malunion and the characteristic "gunstock deformity" (cubitus varus), where the arm angles inward when extended. This deformity is due to improper alignment during healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lateral condyle of humerus fracture:

  • This fracture affects the lateral part of the distal humerus. It can lead to complications like malunion, which may cause a "cubitus valgus" deformity but does not typically result in the "gunstock deformity" (cubitus varus).

Option B - Monteggia fracture:

  • This is a fracture of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head at the elbow. It primarily affects the forearm and elbow stability, but it does not typically cause the "gunstock deformity."

Option D - Shaft of humerus fracture: A fracture of the humeral shaft can cause issues like nerve injury or nonunion, but it does not typically result in the "gunstock deformity."

questions.text: Diphenoxylate is used to treat secretory diarrhea, and it is often combined with atropine. What is the primary reason for this combination therapy?

choices.text: To correct the side effects of diphenoxylate
To enhance the antidiarrheal efficacy of diphenoxylate
To provide an additional antidiarrheal effect
To reduce the potential for abuse of diphenoxylate

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - To reduce the potential for abuse of diphenoxylate:

  • Diphenoxylate is an opioid derivative with antidiarrheal properties. It can potentially be abused due to its opioid-like effects, especially at higher doses. To mitigate the risk of abuse, diphenoxylate is combined with atropine, an anticholinergic agent. The addition of atropine causes unpleasant side effects (such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia) at higher doses, which discourages abuse of the medication.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To correct the side effects of diphenoxylate:

  • Atropine is not added to correct side effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, atropine can add its own set of side effects. The primary purpose of atropine in this combination is to deter abuse, not to alleviate side effects of diphenoxylate.

Option B - To enhance the antidiarrheal efficacy of diphenoxylate:

  • While atropine has some anticholinergic effects that might contribute to reducing diarrhea, its primary role in this combination is not to enhance diphenoxylate’s antidiarrheal efficacy, but rather to deter abuse.

Option C - To provide an additional antidiarrheal effect:

  • Although atropine may provide some additional antidiarrheal effects due to its anticholinergic properties, this is not the main reason for its combination with diphenoxylate. The primary reason is to reduce the potential for abuse of diphenoxylate.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of the demographic cycle in the correct order:


	Early expanding
	High stationary
	Late expanding
	Low stationary
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2, 1, 3, 4:

2. High Stationary Stage: This is the first stage of the demographic cycle, characterized by high birth and death rates. The population growth is slow and fluctuating. Societies at this stage are typically pre-industrial.

1. Early Expanding Stage: In the second stage, the death rate begins to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and food supply, while the birth rate remains high. This leads to a rapid increase in population

3.Late Expanding Stage: The third stage sees a continued decline in the death rate, but the birth rate also starts to decrease due to factors like urbanization, increased access to contraception, and changes in societal values. Population growth starts to slow down.

4. Low Stationary Stage: This is the final stage of the demographic cycle, where both birth and death rates are low, leading to a stable population. Countries in this stage often have high levels of development and a balanced population structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as given above.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and is started on medication to increase norepinephrine levels as part of the treatment plan. Which of the following drugs is used for this purpose, and what is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Methylphenidate:

  • Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant commonly used in the treatment of ADHD. It works by inhibiting the reuptake of both norepinephrine and dopamine, increasing their levels in the brain. This helps improve attention, focus, and impulse control in individuals with ADHD. Although Methylphenidate acts on both norepinephrine and dopamine, it is the increased norepinephrine that contributes significantly to its therapeutic effects in managing ADHD symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Reboxetine:

  • Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that increases norepinephrine levels by inhibiting its reuptake. While it does increase norepinephrine levels and could theoretically be used in ADHD, it is not commonly used for this purpose. Methylphenidate is preferred due to its established efficacy in ADHD treatment.

Option C - Amitriptyline:

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of both norepinephrine and serotonin. It is not typically used to treat ADHD, particularly in children, due to its side effect profile and the availability of more targeted medications like Methylphenidate.

Option D - Fluoxetine:

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that primarily increases serotonin levels. It does not significantly affect norepinephrine levels and is not used to treat ADHD. Fluoxetine is mainly used to treat depression, anxiety, and other mood disorders.

questions.text: Given 500 live births, 12 stillbirths, and 9 deaths within the first 7 days, calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR).
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 18:

  • The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is calculated as the number of deaths of live-born infants within the first 7 days of life per 1000 live births.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: What is the most effective drug to prescribe for a 25-year-old male patient with acne, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Systemic isotretinoin

Explanation:

The photo shows moderate to severe inflammatory acne, characterised by:

  • Numerous papules, pustules, and nodules

  • Scarring and crusting on the lower cheek

  • Evidence of nodulocystic lesions

This type of acne is not responsive to only topical therapies or oral antibiotics in the long term.

Systemic isotretinoin is the most effective treatment for:

  • Severe, nodulocystic acne

  • Acne with scarring

  • Acne that has failed oral antibiotics

  • Acne with significant psychological impact

It works by:

  • Reducing sebaceous gland size and sebum production

  • Normalising keratinisation

  • Reducing inflammation and Cutibacterium acnes colonisation

 

Topical tretinoin (Option A): is incorrect because it is insufficient alone for this level of severity. Used in mild acne or as adjunct.

 

Systemic doxycycline (Option B): is incorrect because while effective in moderate inflammatory acne, it does not adequately control nodulocystic or scarring acne like in the image.

 

Systemic minocycline (Option C): is also a systemic antibiotic alternative to doxycycline but offers no major benefit over doxycycline and has more side effects (e.g., drug-induced lupus, pigmentation).

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NADH dehydrogenase

  • Rotenone inhibits NADH dehydrogenase.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not inhibited by rotenone.

questions.text: Reversal of the muscle relaxant by Vecuronium/rocuronium in patient with Renal failure is normally done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neostigmine:

  • Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor commonly used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as vecuronium and rocuronium. In patients with renal failure, neostigmine is preferred because it does not have the same renal excretion concerns as sugammadex. Neostigmine increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, thereby outcompeting the muscle relaxant and reversing the blockade.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sugammadex:

  • While sugammadex is a highly effective reversal agent for vecuronium and rocuronium, it is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment. Sugammadex is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and its use in patients with renal failure could lead to prolonged action and potential accumulation of the drug.

Option C - Physostigmine:

  • Physostigmine is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade from vecuronium or rocuronium. It is primarily used to counteract anticholinergic toxicity, as it crosses the blood-brain barrier.

Option D - Rivastigmine:

  • Rivastigmine is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade; it is used for treating cognitive symptoms in diseases like Alzheimer’s.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Respiratory failure:

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive lung disease characterized by the gradual scarring of lung tissue, which leads to the deterioration of lung function. The most common cause of death in patients with IPF is respiratory failure. As the disease progresses, the lung tissue becomes increasingly fibrotic, reducing its ability to transfer oxygen into the bloodstream and remove carbon dioxide from it, leading to severe respiratory insufficiency.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pulmonary edema: Pulmonary edema refers to fluid accumulation in the alveoli and interstitial spaces of the lungs, often due to heart failure or other conditions. While it can occur in various pulmonary conditions, it is not the most common cause of death in IPF.

Option C - Cancer: While patients with IPF may have an increased risk of developing lung cancer, cancer is not the most common cause of death in IPF. The primary cause of mortality remains respiratory failure due to progressive lung fibrosis.

Option D - PAH (Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension): Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) can occur as a complication of IPF, but it is not the most common cause of death. PAH can contribute to respiratory failure but is not the primary cause of mortality in IPF.

questions.text: Which of the following stains can be used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Supravital stain:

  • The use of toluidine blue as a supravital stain during direct laryngoscopy is a reliable adjunct to the early and precise diagnosis of carcinoma of the larynx.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not used to identify a laryngeal mass during laryngeal examination.

questions.text: If the incubation period of a disease is 5-14 days, what should be the recommended quarantine period?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 14 days:

  • This is the maximum incubation period, making it the appropriate duration to cover the full range of the incubation period, thus minimizing the risk of spreading the disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth over the penis that is classified as a T3 lesion, with no enlarged inguinal lymph nodes detected. What is the best method of management?

choices.text: Penectomy with superficial/inguinal lymph node dissection(MODIFIED)
Penectomy with deep inguinal lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Penectomy with Superficial/Inguinal Lymph Node Dissection (MODIFIED):

            This involves removing the penis and performing a dissection of the superficial  inguinal lymph nodes. It is done in cases of T3 lesion of tumor but no enlarged or visible lymph nodes as Elective prophylactic lymph node dissection.If superficial lymph nodes becomes positive ,then must go for deep inguinal lymph nodes dissection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option D - Penectomy with Deep Inguinal Lymph Node Dissection: This approach is done with nodal positive cases as Therapeutic lymph node dissection.In this case 1st superficial lymph nodes must be dissected ,if becomes positive go for deep inguinal lymph nodes dissection.

Option A - Penectomy: This procedure involves the surgical removal of the penis. While it addresses the primary tumor, it does not account for potential metastasis to the lymph nodes, which is critical in the management of penile cancer, especially with a T3 lesion indicating a more advanced stage.

Option B - Penectomy with Orchidectomy: This involves the removal of the penis along with the testicles. Orchidectomy is sometimes performed if there is a suspicion of testicular involvement or if the cancer is considered to be related to testicular issues. However, in the absence of evidence of testicular involvement or enlarged lymph nodes, this approach might be excessive and does not specifically address potential regional lymph node metastasis.

.

questions.text: Aprepitant, a drug used to prevent late-onset chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, acts through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NK-1 Antagonist:

  • Mechanism of Action: Aprepitant is a selective antagonist of the neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptor. By blocking the NK-1 receptors, aprepitant inhibits the action of substance P, a neuropeptide involved in the emetic pathway. This helps to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly the late-onset type associated with chemotherapy.
  • Use: It is effective in managing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) when used in combination with other antiemetic agents.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NK-1 Agonist:

  • This is incorrect because aprepitant is not an agonist but an antagonist of the NK-1 receptor. An NK-1 agonist would stimulate the receptor, potentially increasing the risk of nausea and vomiting rather than preventing it.

Option C - NK-3 Antagonist:

  • Aprepitant does not act on the NK-3 receptors. NK-3 receptors are another subtype of neurokinin receptors, and antagonists targeting these receptors are not used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Option D - NK-2 Antagonist:

  • Aprepitant is not an NK-2 antagonist. NK-2 receptors are another subtype involved in the emetic response, but aprepitant specifically targets the NK-1 receptors. NK-2 antagonists are not the primary agents used for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute epigastric pain and an increase in serum lipase levels. Three days after stabilization, a chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most common pathology behind the chest X-ray findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema:

  • In the context of acute pancreatitis, which is indicated by the elevated serum lipase levels and acute epigastric pain, the most common chest X-ray finding could be related to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. This is often a complication of acute pancreatitis due to the release of inflammatory mediators that can lead to increased capillary permeability in the lungs, causing pulmonary edema.
  • The colonic cut-off sign mentioned is a radiographic finding associated with acute pancreatitis, where there is a gas-filled segment of the colon that abruptly ends at the level of the pancreatic inflammation, usually at the splenic flexure. While this sign itself is more directly related to the abdominal pathology, the systemic inflammatory response in severe pancreatitis can lead to complications such as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, reflected in the chest X-ray.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased PCWP (Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure): This finding is typically associated with cardiogenic pulmonary edema, often due to heart failure. In pancreatitis, the pulmonary edema is usually non-cardiogenic, with normal or low PCWP.

Option B - Pulmonary thromboembolism: While pulmonary embolism can present with acute chest pain and respiratory symptoms, it is not typically associated with acute pancreatitis. There would also be other clinical signs, like sudden onset of dyspnea, that are not mentioned in this case.

Option D - Aspiration pneumonitis: This condition occurs due to the inhalation of gastric contents, leading to lung inflammation. It usually presents with respiratory symptoms like coughing and wheezing shortly after the event. There’s no indication in the case of an aspiration event, and it is less likely related to pancreatitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with redness, extreme eye pain, and diminished vision. The patient frequently wears contact lenses. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Acanthamoeba:

  • Acanthamoeba is most likely responsible for this patient's condition. Acanthamoeba keratitis is associated with improper use of contact lenses, and the patients exhibit extreme pain due to perineural invasion.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not responsible for causing this patient’s condition, as explained above.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness during daily activities. On examination, she is unable to make an 'O' shape by opposing her thumb and index finger. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Abductor Pollicis Brevis

Explanation:

The patient’s inability to make an 'O' shape with the thumb and index finger (tip-to-tip pinch) is a classical sign of anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) syndrome, which is a pure motor branch of the median nerve.
 

The AIN innervates deep forearm muscles, specifically:
 

  • Flexor pollicis longus
     
  • Lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus
     
  • Pronator quadratus
     

Hence, the actual motor deficit is due to involvement of FPL and FDP to the index, not due to abductor pollicis brevis or any thenar muscle.
 

However, none of the muscles directly innervated by AIN are listed in the options.
 

Among the choices, the only muscle purely and entirely innervated by the median nerve is abductor pollicis brevis, making it the most appropriate answer based on:
 

  • The nerve implicated (median),
     
  • The pattern of weakness,
     
  • And the available options.
     

Muscles of the Palm: Functions and Innervations

 

 

Muscle Group

Muscles

Function

Innervation

Thenar muscles

• Abductor pollicis brevis

• Flexor pollicis brevis

• Opponens pollicis

• Abducts thumb

 

• Flexes thumb

• Opposes thumb

AbPB: Median nerve (recurrent branch)

FPB: Dual (Median + Ulnar)

OP: Median (variable)

Hypothenar muscles

• Abductor digiti minimi

• Flexor digiti minimi brevis

• Opponens digiti minimi

Controls movement of little finger

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Lumbricals

• 1st & 2nd (lateral)

• 3rd & 4th (medial)

Flex MCPs and extend IP joints

Lateral 2: Median nerve

Medial 2: Ulnar nerve

Palmar interossei

• Three muscles (unipennate)

Adduction of fingers (PAD)

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Dorsal interossei

• Four muscles (bipennate)

Abduction of fingers (DAB)

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Adductor pollicis

• Oblique and transverse heads

Adducts the thumb

Ulnar nerve (deep branch)

Palmaris brevis

• One small superficial muscle

Tenses skin over hypothenar eminence

Ulnar nerve (superficial branch)

 

Opponens pollicis (Option A): Incorrect because it is mainly innervated by the median nerve, but may receive a contribution from the ulnar nerve (dual innervation). Also, it is responsible for thumb opposition, not for the tip-to-tip pinch affected in AIN palsy.
 

Flexor pollicis brevis (Option C): Incorrect. It has dual innervation (superficial head by median, deep head by ulnar). Not purely median.
 

Palmar interossei (Option D): Incorrect. These are ulnar nerve-innervated muscles, unrelated to thumb-index pinch or median nerve pathology.

questions.text: An unconscious patient found to have hot dry skin, dilated pupils, abnormal slurred speech. Most likely overdose is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dhatura:

  • Dhatura (Datura) contains anticholinergic alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. An overdose of Dhatura can lead to anticholinergic syndrome, characterized by hot, dry skin (due to inhibition of sweating), dilated pupils (mydriasis), and altered mental status, which may include slurred speech, confusion, and hallucinations. The combination of these symptoms is classic for anticholinergic toxicity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cannabis:

  • Cannabis intoxication can lead to symptoms such as altered mental status, red eyes, increased appetite, and dry mouth. However, it is not typically associated with hot, dry skin or significant pupil dilation. The symptoms described are more consistent with anticholinergic toxicity rather than cannabis intoxication.

Option C - Alcohol:

  • Alcohol intoxication often presents with symptoms such as slurred speech, incoordination, and altered mental status. However, alcohol does not typically cause hot, dry skin or dilated pupils. In fact, alcohol may lead to hypothermia and constricted pupils in severe cases.

Option D - Cocaine:

  • Cocaine, a stimulant, typically causes symptoms such as dilated pupils, tachycardia, sweating, and agitation. However, it usually does not cause hot, dry skin, which is more characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity. The slurred speech and hot, dry skin are not typical of cocaine intoxication.

questions.text: A patient presents with a nodulo-ulcerative lesion on the lower lip, as shown in the image. What is the best way to take a biopsy in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Excisional biopsy:

  • For a suspicious lesion on the lip, which may be pre-cancerous, an excisional biopsy is the most appropriate method, allowing for complete removal and histopathological examination.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are insufficient.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on the image provided:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Malakoplakia:

  • The given microscopy image reveals Michaelis Guttman bodies, along with cutaneous malakoplakia on the scalp region.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D do not show Michaelis Guttman's bodies.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the immunofluorescence pattern shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pemphigus vulgaris:

  • The fishnet pattern of immunofluorescence observed between keratinocytes in the image is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not show fishnet pattern on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Implantation occurs on which day post fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5

Explanation:

Implantation begins around Day 5 post-fertilization when the blastocyst reaches the uterus and starts attaching to the endometrial lining. The process continues over the next few days, with full implantation completed by Day 9-10.

Fertilisation to Implantation:

Stage

Day (Post-Fertilization)

Key Event

Fertilization

Day 0

Sperm fertilizes oocyte in ampulla of fallopian tube

Zygote Formation

Day 1

Single-cell zygote undergoes cleavage

Morula Formation

Day 3-4

16-cell stage compacted into a solid ball

Blastocyst Formation

Day 5

Fluid-filled cavity forms; blastocyst reaches the uterus

Implantation Begins

Day 5-6

Blastocyst attaches to the endometrium

Trophoblast Invasion

Day 6-8

Syncytiotrophoblast formation, hCG secretion begins

Complete Implantation

Day 9-10

Blastocyst is fully embedded in the endometrial lining

questions.text: A patient has a history of infection by Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) 0157, H7. What does the "H" represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Flagella:

  • The "H" in EHEC 0157, H7, refers to the flagella of Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not denoted by “H”.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea. An ultrasound (USG) shows a cystic ovarian mass with a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis can cause the formation of ovarian cysts known as endometriomas, also called "chocolate cysts." These cysts contain thick, old blood and are characterized by a "ground glass" appearance on ultrasound. This is the correct answer as it best matches the clinical scenario.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intramural fibroid:

  • These are non-cancerous growths within the muscular wall of the uterus. They typically appear as solid masses on ultrasound rather than a cystic mass with a "ground glass" appearance.

Option B - Adenomyoma:

  • This condition involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the uterine muscle, leading to a diffuse or localized thickening of the uterine wall. Ultrasound usually shows a heterogeneous mass in the myometrium, but not a cystic structure with a "ground glass" appearance.

Option D - Myomatous polyp:

  • These are benign growths that arise from the uterine lining or muscle, often presenting as solid, pedunculated masses within the uterine cavity. They do not typically present with a "ground glass" appearance on ultrasound.

questions.text: A patient presented with interstitial lung disease with an occupational history of working in a factory for 20 years and underwent a biopsy. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Asbestosis:

  • The given image shows dumbbell-shaped asbestos bodies, which, along with the history, suggests asbestosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Stanosis: Stanosis occurs due to tin/lead exposure.

Option B – Silicosis: Silicosis will show silicon particles on polarizing microscopy.

Option C – Byssinosis: Byssinosis occurs due to cotton dust/organic dust exposure, which is not mentioned in the patient’s history.

questions.text: Identify the type of uterus shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Didelphys Uterus:

  • The Didelphys Uterus is the correct answer.
  • This condition involves two completely separate uterine cavities, often with dual cervices and sometimes even two vaginas.
  • The image likely showed these distinct, separate uterine structures, indicating a didelphys uterus, distinguishing it from other types of uterine anomalies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bicornuate Uterus:

  • This type of uterus has a deep indentation at the fundus, resulting in a heart-shaped external contour. The cavity is divided into two distinct horns, often giving it a “Y” or “V” shape. It is a congenital anomaly that occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Mullerian ducts.

Option C - Arcuate Uterus:

  • An arcuate uterus is a mild uterine anomaly where the top of the uterus is slightly indented or concave but does not form a significant separation. It is the least severe Mullerian duct anomaly and usually has minimal impact on fertility.

Option D - Aseptate Uterus:

  • An aseptate uterus (or septate uterus) has a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity partially or completely. The external shape of the uterus is typically normal, but the internal cavity is separated by the septum, which can affect pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text: A farmer suffered a wound on the dorsum of his foot. It later involved the subcutaneous tissue and became a discharging ulcer. Microscopy reveals gram-positive branching filaments. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nocardia:

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive bacterium that forms branching filaments and is often associated with causing cutaneous infections in immunocompetent individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sporothrix: Patients with sporotrichosis will usually present with a history of thorn prick followed by ulcers/pustules formation at the trauma site and lymphadenopathy.

Option C - Histoplasma: Histoplasmosis is caused by bat or bird droppings and affects the reticuloendothelial system.

Option D - Candida: On microscopy, candida will appear as both buds and pseudohyphae forms.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine is kept at lowest level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - OPV:

  • The OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is kept at the lowest level in Intermediate-Level Refrigerators (ILRs) compared to the other vaccines listed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): DPT is a combination vaccine and is sensitive to temperature changes. It needs to be stored in a controlled environment to maintain its efficacy, typically at a temperature range of 2°C to 8°C in ILRs.

Option C - Hep B (Hepatitis B Vaccine): Hepatitis B vaccine is sensitive to temperature and must be kept at a stable temperature of 2°C to 8°C, similar to DPT, but it is more sensitive to freezing. Thus, it requires careful monitoring to avoid freezing.

Option D - Rota (Rotavirus Vaccine): The Rotavirus vaccine is sensitive to temperature fluctuations and is generally stored in ILRs at 2°C to 8°C. However, it is often kept at a higher level in the cold chain to ensure stability.

questions.text: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. An ultrasound (USG) shows distention of the portal vein, and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been administered. What is the next appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement:

  • The patient is presenting with severe hematemesis, which suggests significant blood loss. The immediate priority is stabilizing the patient by administering intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, replace lost fluids, and correct electrolyte imbalances.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics: While antibiotics may be needed later in managing a patient with suspected variceal bleeding and cirrhosis (to prevent infections like spontaneous bacterial peritonitis), it is not the immediate next step. The priority is to stabilize the patient first.

Option B - Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis: A liver biopsy is useful for diagnosing the extent of liver fibrosis or cirrhosis. However, in the acute setting of severe hematemesis, it is inappropriate as the immediate next step. The patient needs urgent stabilization, not an invasive diagnostic procedure.

Option D - Perform an endoscopy to look for varices: Endoscopy is essential for diagnosing and managing variceal bleeding, particularly in a patient with portal hypertension secondary to chronic alcohol use. However, it should be performed after initial stabilization, including fluid resuscitation and hemodynamic support.

questions.text: Patient presenting with pain in back of thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights. Which segment is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - S2:

  • Pain in the back of the thigh and leg after lifting heavy weights is most commonly associated with the S2 nerve root. The S2 nerve root contributes to the sensation in the posterior aspect of the thigh and leg and can be affected by conditions such as sciatica or disc herniation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L4: The L4 nerve root typically affects the anterior and medial aspect of the thigh, as well as the medial side of the leg and foot. It is less likely to be associated with pain specifically in the back of the thigh and leg.

Option B - L5: The L5 nerve root affects the lateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. While it can cause pain radiating down the leg, it is not typically associated with pain specifically in the back of the thigh.

Option C - S1: The S1 nerve root affects the posterior and lateral aspects of the leg and the heel. Pain in the back of the thigh and leg can be related to S1, but S2 is more directly associated with the described pain after heavy lifting.

questions.text: Who order the autopsy in case of RTA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Police:

In cases of Road Traffic Accidents (RTA), the police are responsible for ordering an autopsy to determine the cause of death. This is part of their duty to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death and to ensure proper legal procedures are followed. The police will request an autopsy if there is a need to understand the cause of death more clearly or if it is required for legal reasons.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Forensic expert:

A forensic expert conducts the autopsy but does not order it. The role of the forensic expert is to perform the examination and provide a report based on their findings.

Option C - Lawyer:

A lawyer may request an autopsy as part of legal proceedings, but they do not have the authority to order an autopsy in cases of RTA. Their role is generally more related to the legal representation of the parties involved.

Option D - Forensic doctor:

Similar to the forensic expert, the forensic doctor performs the autopsy but does not order it. The forensic doctor provides medical expertise in the examination and interpretation of findings.

questions.text: A child presents with deformities, normal serum calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated ALP. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 1 (VDDR type 1)
Vitamin D Dependent Rickets Type 2 (VDDR type 2)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypophosphatemic rickets:

  • Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low phosphate levels, normal calcium and PTH, and elevated ALP, leading to bone deformities.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B and C - VDDR type 1 & 2 present with low calcium and elevated PTH.

Option D - Renal osteodystrophy will present with underlying renal disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm and has a dietary history of Vitamin A and C deficiency. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Phrynoderma:

  • Phrynoderma: Also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, this condition is characterized by small, rough papules, typically on the extensor surfaces of limbs, due to Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Scurvy is caused by Vitamin C deficiency; it presents with symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, and joint pain, not follicular hyperkeratosis.

Option C - Pellagra is caused by niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency, presenting with the classic triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

Option D - Keratosis pilaris is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Identify the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sapna Leprosy:

  • This is the correct answer. The "Sapna" campaign is linked to leprosy awareness in India, symbolizing hope and the possibility of a future free from leprosy-related stigma and disease.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Arohi from HIV: This option may refer to a character or campaign related to HIV awareness, but it is not the correct association for the image related to leprosy.

Option C - Meena UNICEF: The Meena campaign, supported by UNICEF, focuses on gender equality and education for girls in South Asia. It is not related to leprosy or the image in question.

questions.text: What are the effects of a lesion in Brodmann area 22?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Receptive aphasia:

  • Brodmann area 22, also known as Wernicke's area, is primarily responsible for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to difficulties in understanding spoken and written language, resulting in receptive aphasia. Patients with this condition can speak fluently but often produce nonsensical sentences and have trouble understanding others.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Expressive aphasia: This is typically associated with damage to Brodmann area 44 and 45 (Broca's area) rather than Brodmann area 22. Expressive aphasia affects speech production, making it difficult for the patient to form grammatically correct sentences.

Option C - Poor repetition of language: Poor repetition of language is often linked to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's area and Broca's area, rather than directly to Brodmann area 22.

Option D - Poor naming: Poor naming is often associated with damage to areas involved in language processing and retrieval, such as the left temporal lobe, but not specifically with Brodmann area 22 alone.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident (RTA). He presents with confusion, irritability, and tremors. The patient has a history of daily alcohol consumption. Which drug is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lorazepam:

  • Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which is the drug of choice for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.
  • Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, including anxiety, seizures, and delirium tremens (DTs).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D have no role in treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: What is the confirmatory test for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NMR Spectroscopy:

  • When differentiating between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis in cases of ring-enhancing lesions, NMR Spectroscopy (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy) provides detailed metabolic and chemical information about the brain lesions. This technique can help differentiate between various types of lesions based on their biochemical signatures, making it valuable in distinguishing between tuberculomas (due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and neurocysticercosis (due to Taenia solium).
  • NMR Spectroscopy analyzes the metabolic byproducts and chemical composition of the lesions, which can help in differentiating between conditions like tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis. It can provide information about the presence of specific metabolites and biochemical changes associated with each condition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CBNAAT of CSF:

  • While CBNAAT is excellent for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA and is very useful in diagnosing CNS tuberculosis, it is not typically used to distinguish between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis directly. It confirms the presence of tuberculosis but does not provide biochemical information about the lesion itself.

Option B - PET Scan:

  • PET scans show metabolic activity in tissues and can be helpful in assessing lesions, but they do not provide detailed biochemical or chemical information specific to tuberculoma vs. neurocysticercosis. They are more used for overall lesion characterization rather than definitive diagnosis.

Option D - MRI aerial scan:

  • This term is not a standard diagnostic modality in clinical practice. MRI is used to visualize lesions and their characteristics but does not provide specific confirmation of tuberculoma or neurocysticercosis. It helps in lesion assessment but is not confirmatory for distinguishing between these two conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will cause Torsades de pointes if given with erythromycin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Astemizole:

  • Astemizole is an antihistamine that has been associated with QT interval prolongation, a risk factor for Torsades de pointes, a type of life-threatening ventricular tachycardia. Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) enzyme. Astemizole is metabolized by CYP3A4, and when given together, erythromycin can increase the levels of astemizole, leading to significant QT prolongation and a high risk of Torsades de pointes. Due to this risk, astemizole has been withdrawn from the market in many countries.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can also cause QT interval prolongation. However, when given with erythromycin, the risk of Torsades de pointes is lower compared to astemizole because levofloxacin is not as strongly influenced by CYP3A4 interactions.

Option C - Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that does not prolong the QT interval and is not associated with Torsades de pointes, either alone or in combination with erythromycin.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that also does not prolong the QT interval or interact with erythromycin to increase the risk of Torsades de pointes.

questions.text: Patient presents with features of right heart failure and exhibits a rapid Y descent on cardiac examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium becomes thickened and fibrotic, leading to impaired filling of the heart, particularly the right side. A rapid Y descent on jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a classic finding in constrictive pericarditis, reflecting rapid early diastolic filling of the ventricle due to the rigid pericardium. The patient may present with signs of right heart failure, such as peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with a blunted or absent Y descent on JVP tracing due to the equalization of pressures during diastole, which restricts ventricular filling. The presence of a rapid Y descent makes cardiac tamponade less likely.

Option C - Pulmonary Hypertension: Pulmonary hypertension can cause right heart failure, but it is not associated with a rapid Y descent on JVP. The JVP findings in pulmonary hypertension are usually more related to elevated pressure rather than specific waveforms like a rapid Y descent.

Option D - Right Ventricular Infarction: Right ventricular infarction can present with signs of right heart failure. However, the JVP typically shows an elevated a-wave or a prominent X descent, not a rapid Y descent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, gravida 2, para 2, with a history of cervical lengthening, is considering surgical options. Given her history, what is the choice of surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fothergill Procedure

Explanation:

  • The Fothergill procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical incompetence. It involves shortening the cervix to strengthen it, typically used in cases of cervical incompetence where there is a need to support the cervix during pregnancy to prevent preterm delivery.
  • Indication: Used for cervical incompetence in cases where previous cervical lengthening or other methods have failed.

Incorrect Options:

(Option B) McCall Culdoplasty:

  • Explanation: McCall culdoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to support the vaginal apex (top of the vagina) and prevent prolapse. It is commonly used in the context of post-hysterectomy pelvic support.
  • Indication: Primarily used for pelvic organ prolapse or after a hysterectomy, not specifically for cervical incompetence.

(Option C) LeFort Procedure:

  • Explanation: The LeFort procedure is a type of pelvic reconstructive surgery, but it is more commonly associated with treating conditions related to pelvic support after a hysterectomy or in cases of prolapse.
  • Indication: Usually not used for cervical incompetence; more applicable to pelvic reconstructive issues.

(Option D) Hysterectomy:

  • Explanation: Hysterectomy is the surgical removal of the uterus. It is not typically used to address cervical incompetence directly but is performed for conditions like fibroids, cancer, or severe endometriosis.
  • Indication: This is not the first choice for cervical incompetence; it would only be considered if there were other significant indications for removing the uterus.

questions.text: Aldrich mees lines and raindrop pigmentation in hand is seen in which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arsenic:

Aldrich-Mees lines (transverse white lines across the nails) and raindrop pigmentation (brownish discoloration) on the hands are characteristic signs of arsenic poisoning. Arsenic is known to cause these distinctive dermatological and nail changes. Arsenic interferes with the keratinization process in the nails, leading to the formation of Mees lines, and can cause pigmentary changes in the skin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thallium:

Thallium poisoning can cause symptoms like hair loss, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal issues, but it is not typically associated with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Thallium poisoning does have its own set of diagnostic signs but these specific ones are not characteristic.

Option C - Cadmium:

Cadmium poisoning is associated with kidney damage and bone disease, not with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Cadmium does not produce the same dermatological findings as arsenic.

Option D - Lead:

Lead poisoning is associated with basophilic stippling of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with Aldrich-Mees lines or raindrop pigmentation. Lead affects different body systems and has different clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD by his parents with complaints of recurrent infections. On mediastinal imaging, the thymus gland was found to be absent. Based on further investigation, ADA levels are low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Severe combined immunodeficiency:

  • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by a lack of both T and B cells, leading to severe immune deficiency. Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is seen in autosomal recessive SCID.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C do not have ADA deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with the following presentation. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Operate immediately:

  • In this situation, the image reveals bilateral congenital cataracts, meaning both eyes are affected. If not treated promptly, this condition can result in irreversible vision loss due to amblyopia. For bilateral cataracts, surgery is typically performed after the child reaches one month of age, so immediate surgery is necessary in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: The PR interval was measured at 0.21 seconds in a routine ECG of the patient. What is the correct Interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - First degree HB:

  • First-degree heart block is defined by a prolonged PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds (200 milliseconds). In this case, a PR interval of 0.21 seconds indicates a prolonged PR interval, which is characteristic of first-degree heart block.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Second degree HB: Second-degree heart block (HB) is characterized by intermittent failure of some atrial impulses to be conducted to the ventricles. This is usually identified by a pattern of dropped beats or a varying PR interval. The PR interval in second-degree HB can be normal or prolonged, but it does not specifically represent a fixed interval as seen in first-degree HB.

Option C - Normal rhythm: A normal PR interval ranges from 0.12 to 0.20 seconds. A PR interval of 0.21 seconds exceeds this range, indicating that the rhythm is not normal.

Option D - Complete HB: Complete heart block (also known as third-degree heart block) is characterized by a complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity, with no correlation between P waves and QRS complexes. The PR interval is not applicable in this context as the atrial impulses do not conduct to the ventricles.

questions.text: For a woman with a 10-week period of gestation (POG) who seeks medical termination of pregnancy, the appropriate choice would be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mifepristone and Misoprostol:

  • Mifepristone: This is a progesterone antagonist that blocks the effects of progesterone, which is necessary to maintain pregnancy. It prepares the uterus for the subsequent action of misoprostol.
  • Misoprostol: This is a prostaglandin analog that induces uterine contractions and helps expel the contents of the uterus. It is used after mifepristone to complete the abortion process.
  • Usage: This combination is widely used for medical abortion up to 10 weeks gestation and is considered safe and effective.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dinoprost:

Dinoprost: This is a prostaglandin used to induce labor and terminate pregnancies. However, it is typically used in the second trimester rather than at 10 weeks POG. It is less commonly used compared to misoprostol for early medical abortion.

Option C - Oxytocin:

Oxytocin: This is a hormone used to induce labor by stimulating uterine contractions. It is not used for early medical abortion and is generally reserved for labor induction or management of postpartum hemorrhage.

Option D - Intrauterine Hyperosmolar Saline:

Intrauterine Hyperosmolar Saline: This is an older method of abortion used in the second trimester and involves injecting a hyperosmolar saline solution into the amniotic sac. It is not used for early-term abortions and is less common in modern practice.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department with a history of fall and head injury. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Subdural Hematoma (SDH):

  • Appears as a crescent-shaped, hyperdense or isodense lesion on a CT scan, located between the dura mater and the brain's surface. It is commonly associated with bridging vein rupture, often seen in cases of trauma or in the elderly. It often has a more diffuse and irregular boundary compared to EDH.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epidural Hematoma (EDH): Typically appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on a CT scan, located between the dura mater and the skull. It is usually associated with a skull fracture and tends to have a more well-defined boundary. It occurs due to rupture of the meningeal arteries.

Option C - Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Typically appears as hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain on a CT scan. It is often diffuse and can be seen around the sulci and ventricles. It usually occurs due to the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation.

Option D - Contusion: Appears as localized areas of hemorrhage within the brain tissue itself. On a CT scan, it often shows as areas of mixed density with associated edema, and it is typically more focal rather than diffuse or crescent-shaped.

questions.text: Which sinus drainage is obstructed in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Maxillary:

  • The given radiograph shows blockage in both the maxillary sinuses, predominantly in the right maxillary sinus.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are not obstructed in the given X-ray.

questions.text: Loading dose of drug is dependent on:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Volume of distribution:

  • The loading dose of a drug is calculated to rapidly achieve the desired plasma concentration of the drug. It is primarily dependent on the volume of distribution (Vd), which reflects the extent to which a drug is distributed in the body tissues relative to the plasma. The formula for loading dose is:

 

  • This equation shows that the loading dose is directly proportional to the volume of distribution.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clearance:

  • Clearance is related to the maintenance dose rather than the loading dose. It represents the rate at which the drug is removed from the body and is important for determining the dosing rate needed to maintain a steady-state concentration, not for calculating the loading dose.

Option B - Route of administration:

  • The route of administration can affect the bioavailability of a drug, but it does not directly determine the loading dose. The loading dose is based on the volume of distribution and desired plasma concentration, though the bioavailability factor must be considered if the drug is not administered intravenously.

Option D - Bioavailability:

  • Bioavailability (F) does play a role in the calculation of the loading dose, particularly for non-intravenous routes where F is less than 1. However, the loading dose is fundamentally based on the volume of distribution, with bioavailability adjusting the dose for non-IV routes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adipocere formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Preservation by saponification:

Adipocere formation, also known as "grave wax," is a process where body fat turns into a waxy substance due to saponification. This process involves the hydrolysis of fats in the body by bacteria, leading to the formation of a soapy, wax-like substance that helps in the preservation of the body.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High temperature needed:

Adipocere formation generally occurs in a cool, moist environment. High temperatures are not conducive to this process; rather, the process is enhanced in cooler conditions which slow down decomposition and support the saponification process.

Option C - Cool and dry climate needed:

While a cool climate can favor adipocere formation, a dry climate is not ideal. Adipocere formation requires moisture to facilitate the saponification process. Therefore, a cool and moist environment is more conducive to adipocere formation.

Option D - Occurs within minutes to hours:

Adipocere formation is a relatively slow process that can take several weeks to months to develop fully, not minutes to hours.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Burn-Marshall Maneuver:

  • The Burn-Marshall Maneuver (often referred to as the "Burns" maneuver) is used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech delivery. The baby is allowed to hang until the nape of the neck is visible. Gentle upward traction is applied to the fetal body to deliver the head. However, in the context of delivering the shoulders, the term may be incorrectly used; the correct term would generally be "Lovset Maneuver."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lovset Maneuver:

  • This maneuver is used to deliver the shoulders during a breech birth. The fetal body is rotated to facilitate the delivery of the anterior shoulder, followed by the posterior shoulder.

Option C - Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit Maneuver:

  • This maneuver is used to assist the delivery of the head in a breech presentation. The fetal body is supported on the physician’s arm, and fingers are placed in the fetal mouth to provide flexion of the head while applying gentle pressure on the occiput.

questions.text: Identify the bullet range
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Close range:

When a gunshot wound shows blackening and tattooing around it, this indicates a close-range shot. Blackening is caused by the deposition of soot and gunpowder residue from the burning propellant, while tattooing is due to the impact of unburned powder particles. These signs are typically seen when the muzzle is relatively close to the target, usually within a few feet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Distant range:

At a distant range, the wound would not exhibit blackening or tattooing because the gunpowder residues would not have had a chance to settle on the skin. Distant range wounds usually present with a clean entry wound without additional residues.

Option B - Close contact:

Close contact wounds are typically characterized by a much more severe pattern, such as a star-shaped wound with burning and possibly charring of the skin. The presence of blackening and tattooing suggests a somewhat less extreme range, but still close.

Option D - Cannot be predicted:

The presence of blackening and tattooing can indeed predict the bullet range with a reasonable degree of certainty. Therefore, this option is not accurate as the gunshot range can be estimated based on these features.

questions.text: Identify the defect shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Homonymous hemianopia:

  • The given image shows homonymous hemianopia. Homonymous hemianopia refers to the loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes, meaning that the patient loses vision on either the left or right side in both eyes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Binasal hemianopia: Involves the loss of the nasal (inner) half of the visual field in both eyes.

Option B - Bitemporal hemianopia: Involves the loss of the temporal (outer) half of the visual field in both eyes.

Option D - Altitudinal defect: Refers to the loss of the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anencephaly:

  • This condition is characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain and skull. On ultrasound, it presents as the absence of a normal brain structure, but it does not typically display the "Frog Eye Sign."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hydranencephaly:

  • This condition involves the replacement of brain tissue with cerebrospinal fluid, leading to a near-complete absence of cerebral hemispheres. The ultrasound appearance is more consistent with the absence of cerebral hemispheres and a large fluid-filled cavity rather than the "Frog Eye Sign."

Option C - Spina Bifida:

Markers for Spina Bifida

  • Scalloping of frontal bones: Lemon Sign
  • Forward curvature of Cerebellum: Banana Sign

Option D - Lissencephaly:

  • This is a condition characterized by a smooth brain surface due to a lack of normal gyri and sulci. On ultrasound, it shows a smooth cerebral cortex without the typical folding patterns, but it does not typically present with the "Frog Eye Sign."

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a long-standing history of fever presents with discoloration of the skin over the lower limb and edema. Microscopy reveals a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wuchereria bancrofti:

  • Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis. The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi’s microfilariae have two nuclei that extend to the tip of the tail.

Option C - Loa Loa: The microfilariae of Loa Loa are sheathed, but the nuclei form a continuous row at the tip of the tail.

Option D - Mansonelia: The microfilariae of Mansonelia are unsheathed and extend to the tip of the tail.

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and flank pain. A renal mass is shown in the image provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma:

  • Chromophobe RCC has a distinct histological appearance, which shows plant cells, perinuclear halos, and raisinoid nuclei. It also shows positivity with Hale's colloidal iron stain and has a better prognosis compared to other RCC types.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not show plant cells.

questions.text: A singer presents with singing at high pitch. On examination, bowing of the vocal cord is seen on the right side. Which of the following muscles has been compromised?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cricothyroid:

  • The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing and elongating the vocal cords, which is crucial for producing high-pitched sounds. When the cricothyroid muscle is compromised, it can lead to an inability to tense the vocal cords properly, resulting in bowing or a lack of tension, particularly during high-pitched singing. This bowing may be observed on laryngoscopy as a gap between the vocal cords, contributing to a weak or breathy voice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Posterior cricoarytenoid:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords. If this muscle were compromised, the vocal cords would remain in a partially closed position, leading to difficulty breathing rather than issues with pitch.

Option B - Lateral cricoarytenoid:

  • The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle adducts (closes) the vocal cords. Its impairment would affect the closure of the vocal cords, leading to issues with sound production, but not specifically related to pitch.

Option D - Thyroarytenoid:

  • The thyroarytenoid muscle helps to shorten and relax the vocal cords, lowering the pitch. While it plays a role in vocal cord tension, it is more involved in lower pitches and overall voice modulation rather than the high-pitch tension that the cricothyroid muscle manages.

questions.text: How does the graft get nutrition on day 3?
questions.solution:
Correct option B -Inosculation

         On day 3 ,  inosculation starts in which graft and host vessels form anastomosis.This means capillary buds from the recipient bed begin to connect with the graft’s vessels, allowing some blood flow and nutrient delivery.

Day Nutritional Mechanism
0–2 Plasmatic imbibition (diffusion)
~3 Inosculation (capillary connections form)
4–7 Neovascularization (new vessels grow in)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option  A- Imbibition:Occurs during the first 24–48 hours after graft placement.The graft absorbs nutrients, oxygen, and plasma passively by diffusion from the vascular bed of the recipient site..

 

Option C - Neovascularization: Neovascularization involves the growth of new blood vessels into the graft from the host tissue. This process generally begins more than 5 days after the graft is placed and is crucial for sustaining the graft over the long term by providing a more robust blood supply.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a gradually progressive hearing loss in her right ear, accompanied by pulsatile tinnitus. On otoscopic examination, a red vascular mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glomus Tympanicum:

  • Glomus Tympanicum is characterized by a red vascular mass seen on otoscopy. It originates from the paraganglionic cells and is known for causing pulsatile tinnitus, as well as conductive hearing loss. The given image shows Phelp sign, which further confirms the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not exhibit Phelp sign.

questions.text: What is this grid system used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prolapse:

  • The POP-Q (Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification) system is specifically designed to assess and classify pelvic organ prolapse. It provides a standardized method to evaluate the extent and severity of prolapse, allowing for more accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

Incorrect options B, C and D:

  • The POP-Q system is not used for diagnosing or managing vulvar cancer. Endometrial cancer or Abruption placenta.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient with a 10-day history of binge drinking presents with altered sensorium, slurred speech, and unconsciousness, with a blood glucose level of 49 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Intravenous thiamine infusion followed by dextrose
Intravenous vitamin K followed by dextrose

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intravenous thiamine infusion followed by dextrose:

  • In an alcoholic patient with altered sensorium, slurred speech, and hypoglycemia, it is crucial to administer intravenous thiamine before dextrose. Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, increasing the risk of Wernicke's encephalopathy when glucose is given without prior thiamine. Thiamine is a cofactor required for glucose metabolism, and administering glucose without thiamine can exacerbate neurologic symptoms due to the increased metabolic demand.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intravenous vitamin K followed by dextrose: Vitamin K is used in cases of coagulopathy, especially with elevated INR in patients with liver disease or on anticoagulants. It has no role in the acute management of hypoglycemia or in preventing Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Option C - Only dextrose infusion: While dextrose will correct the hypoglycemia, administering it without thiamine can precipitate or worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy in patients with thiamine deficiency.

Option D - Oral thiamine followed by dextrose: In acute settings, oral thiamine is insufficient due to its slower absorption and delayed action. Intravenous administration ensures rapid availability to prevent neurological complications.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized body aches, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hairs on her arms, and white lines of Frenkel on X-ray as shown below. This clinical presentation is most consistent with which of the following deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Correct  Option B - Vitamin C deficiency:

  • Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) is known for causing anemia, bleeding gums, and skin changes.
  • Collagen is the backbone of blood vessels, in scurvy due to improper collagen synthesis, blood vessels become fragile resulting in bleeding
    • Gum bleeding
    • Painful pseudo paralysis of lower limbs, so there is crying on touching Subperiosteal hemorrhage of long bones.
    • Scorbutic rosary i.e., prominence of the costochondral junction which is sharper, tender, and angulated as compared to rachitic rosary.
  • Xray show "lines of Frenkel" on X-ray.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zinc deficiency:

  • Zinc deficiency can cause growth retardation, skin changes, and immune dysfunction. However, the specific feature of "lines of Frenkel" is not typically associated with zinc deficiency.

Option C - Copper deficiency:

  • Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, and depigmentation of the hair and skin. 

Option D - Iron deficiency:
